TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister to recall his first unsuccessful challenge to the then Opposition Leader, Mr Bill Hayden, in July 1982. I remind the Prime Minister that after that challenge he gave an unqualified guarantee that there would be no further challenge before the next election. —I ask the Minister for Community Services and Health to inform the House what the transfer to his portfolio of the housing industry function means for the national housing strategy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The national housing strategy is a broad strategy that not only includes social housing and social considerations but also goes to the structure of the industry. The change with respect to the portfolio will assist in terms of coordination of the response that comes out of the national housing strategy.

ANSWER.PARA: There are some key issues in terms of housing that are being addressed as part of the housing strategy. There are questions of choice in terms of housing needs. I think it is becoming clear, and people who have read the early papers on the national housing strategy will understand, that our housing stock in this country does not match the needs of Australians because the types of households that Australians live in have changed, are changing and will change further over the next 25 years. The national housing strategy's primary objective is to develop policy which will enable the housing industry to deliver appropriate and affordable housing for all Australians.

Appropriate housing will mean a greater variety in the types of housing we build and better links between housing and the services that people need. Affordable housing means looking at new ways of building housing through initiatives such as the Green Street joint venture, higher density housing in established suburbs and better use of capital investment in infrastructure.

Reform of the relations between Commonwealth, State and local government is also essential because of State and local government responsibilities for regulation of service delivery. The work being done by the national housing strategy necessarily involves the housing construction industry. The Government will be talking to all the main players through the housing industry development strategy and the national housing strategy consultations. I will be hosting in early July an Australian Housing Research Council meeting which will be attended by State Ministers, representatives of housing and finance industry bodies and local government, community organisations and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The housing industry is clearly an extremely important part of the Australian economy. The national housing strategy, the housing industry development strategy and reform of Commonwealth-State relations will remove barriers to the housing industry's efficient operation and increase its efficiency and competitiveness by lowering its cost structure.

In conclusion, there needs to be change in terms of housing in this country. We need to look at the quality, the affordability and the choice available to all Australians in relation to housing. In this nation something like 80 per cent of all dwellings are single detached houses. Only 13 per cent of dwellings in Australia are medium density. At the same time as we have seen a decline in average family size, the density in house sizes has risen from 13 squares in the 1970s to over 18 squares now. We are building increasingly at the edge of our cities larger and more generous houses in terms of squareage while the affordability of Australian housing effectively goes down.

If we are concerned about both efficiency objectives and social justice objectives, then the access to quality housing of ordinary Australians needs to be given much greater emphasis. Out of the national housing strategy I believe we will build a consensus between the Commonwealth, the States and local government. Through the Australian Housing Research Council all of the major players in the industry, together with the Government, will be able to help us chart more affordable housing built in cities which are more humane and which better express the needs of average Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable member that that is the situation with Telecom. It is generally about this time of the year, Budget time, that there is a great deal of publicity associated with what Telecom's financial status is supposed to be.

In dealing with the problems confronting Telecom, if it confronts any, it is making appropriate adjustments to its capital program and, even more important, in relation to its productivity by cutting staff costs. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to Medicare, as I have indicated in Parliament before, there is very clear support by the Australian people for a universal health insurance system. Nevertheless, we have seen proposals being developed within the Liberal Party of Australia and its various branches that I think have some implications for my portfolio and, indeed, for the future of Medicare.

ANSWER.PARA: It is argued that there are deficiencies that need to be tackled. We heard that in relation to the Australian Capital Territory branch, and here is another branch of the Liberal Party, in this case the South Australian branch of the Liberal Party-Dale Baker, Leader of the Opposition and Michael Armitage, shadow Minister for health. What is argued there is that--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Downer?

—The honourable member for Mayo, I guess, is comfortable. What is argued there is that many of the ideological deficiencies must be tackled federally; the inefficiencies in the provision of universal health care are a matter primarily for the Commonwealth Government to acknowledge and address, but it may not be tackled in any meaningful way until a Federal Liberal government with a different ideology is in office. Certainly a most pressing need is to induce more people to be responsible for their own well-being by entering private health insurance funds; and the present health system provides little incentive for many who can afford it to take out private insurance.

ANSWER.PARA: So, in terms of the debate in relation to health insurance, a second State branch of the Liberal Party in Australia has indicated its position: the dismantling of Medicare and the privatisation of the health system. We have seen that debate begun and then aborted in this Parliament in terms of the Leader of the Opposition's floating of the idea of the health voucher-he throws it up, then away quickly, and the debate goes on, simmering away, State branch after State branch, towards the dismantling of Medicare.

We have to ask what this will mean for Australians. What it will mean is no automatic access to free hospital and medical care. The fundamental bases of Medicare, those of universal coverage and equity of access, are to be destroyed. Under Medicare, an individual's contribution to the costs of the health system is related to the capacity to pay. Under Liberal proposals, the poor and the sick would pay more and the wealthy would pay less.

This is not a debate about equity only. As people who have been to the United States will know, it has a system dominated in fact by private insurance, a system which is rationed by private insurance in terms of affordability-those who can afford to pay get health treatment; those who cannot do not have the same accessibility. And it is costing nearly 12 per cent of gross domestic product compared to Australia's performance, which is keeping the cost of Medicare to around 8 per cent of GDP, right through the 1980s and indeed through the 1990s, as we tackle the issues and provide Australians with something that is fair, equitable and efficient.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australia Council, as the Government's principal arts funding body, is no doubt concerned about this low application rate and is taking measures to address the issues it raises. I know that the general manager of the Australia Council was gratified when a number of brochures and application forms were made available to a wide group of people in the arts community in far north Queensland. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some concerns have been raised about the Government's intention in its legislation as a result of the passage of the legislation through this House prior to its consideration by the Senate. Honourable members will have noticed in that legislation the intention of the Government to establish a national planning code to provide a predictable and national approach to the development of telecommunications infrastructure. It will maximise protection of the environment and set in place appropriate design standards and planning procedures. It will cover facilities which are exempted from the application of State laws and the code will impose more comprehensive obligations and restrictions on both carriers than currently apply to either Telecom Australia or OTC Ltd.

ANSWER.PARA: It represents a considerable winding back of Telecom's current exemption from all State, Territory and local government laws. For the first time, telecommunications facilities will be subject to external environmental regulation and accountability and, until the time that the code is established, the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation will remain subject to the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, a Commonwealth Act; and interim guidelines, included in their licence conditions, will apply to both carriers. Power will be given to Austel to enforce the code and to give directions to the carriers on how the code is to apply. The result will be uniform processes which will also enable a second carrier to roll out its network in the shortest possible time.

As to that national environmental code, as with everything else we have done in the telecommunications area, we will be very pleased to receive advice from the community and other sections of government departments, from the Opposition for that matter, from the Australian Democrats and from others in the community who have a concern in the environmental area. It is not being regarded as an exclusive activity simply conducted by us, and when that code comes into place, it will be enforced.

It is essential that in this area we do have national legislation. It is not possible or sensible to subject the development of a national communications infrastructure to unfettered interference by State and local planning laws. The consequences of that would be potentially highly damaging both for Telecom Australia in its current infrastructure and for the new carrier as it rolls it out. But this will be a matter of concern, I know, for the Opposition and the Democrats in the Senate, and I am prepared to give an undertaking-and no doubt my spokesman in the Senate will do so also-that as this national code is developed there will be consultation with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Corio for a question that I would have to say is very definitely without notice, so points of order that might be taken that somehow it is not integral to my portfolio have some sympathy in that sense. Let me say that the issues which have been raised by the honourable member for Corio are obviously issues that do need to be considered when one thinks about taxation policy and its social impact. Of course, in terms of the Government's thinking, we have had considerable opportunity now over eight years to consider a whole range of options in relation to taxation, including a proposed consumption tax. At the time when such a proposal was included in the Treasury White Paper on taxation, I was Minister for Social Security and I had the opportunity in that portfolio to give very great consideration to any social impacts that might occur as a result of the introduction of such a tax.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed rate at that time was of the order of 12.5 per cent, and we were able to do some modelling to indicate the level of compensation that would be required, particularly to cover disadvantaged people. When we did that, it raised quite serious problems because the fact of the matter is that expenditure is skewed in terms of the income distribution; that is, those people who are at the lowest end of the income distribution are in fact people who tend to spend more on direct consumption goods such as food-they spend a much higher proportion of their income on the kinds of essentials that were referred to by the honourable member for Corio.

The result of that means that there are considerable difficulties in designing any effective compensation. Indeed, the fact that it was impossible to provide effective compensation was a factor in the Government's decision at that time not to proceed with a consumption tax. There is, as I think the question of the honourable member for Corio hints, a fundamental inequity involved in a tax that is regressive in its impact on low income people. That is why the Government rejected it then and is aware of the political debate that will develop in this country about the levels of consumption tax that are likely to be proposed by Opposition members, who seem to want to talk about a proposal with a degree of firmness, except at the point that one questions a particular detail.

There is one final point that I would make in response to the honourable member's question about a consumption tax: it is very difficult indeed to compensate to, in any sense, deal with the inequities that are provided. Therefore, the Government's decision at that time reflected its concern, which has been followed through in terms of taxation policy which has been progressive and which has enabled us, together with social security policy that has been highly targeted, to produce a much fairer distribution of income in this country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TREATY ON THE NON-PROLIFERATION OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. Can he advise honourable members of the Government's reaction to the decision by France to adhere to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Denison for his question. As honourable members know, yesterday President Mitterrand made a comprehensive statement of France's approach to the control of weapons of mass destruction as well as conventional weapons. The President announced France's in-principle decision to sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and expressed the wish that all states adhere to it.

ANSWER.PARA: We in Australia very much welcome this decision, which is a further step in strengthening the international non-proliferation regime in the wake of the Gulf war. At both the prime ministerial and ministerial level, we have long urged France to sign the Non-Proliferation Treaty and to require full scope safeguards as a condition for new nuclear supply. Under the Non-Proliferation Treaty, nuclear weapon states undertake, by article 1, not to transfer nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices or in any way assist other states to acquire them and, according to article 6, to pursue the negotiation for the cessation of the nuclear arms race and a treaty on general and complete disarmament.

The treaty does not require nuclear weapons states which are parties to it to cease nuclear tests. Australia's position on the urgent need for a comprehensive test ban and its position against French nuclear testing in the South Pacific remains unchanged. Nevertheless France's very welcome decision to adhere to the Non-Proliferation Treaty means that China remains the only nuclear weapons state that is outside the treaty. We hope that China will now also take the step which Australia has long urged China to do.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. What progress has been made in the implementation of the Hawke Government's policy to provide access to good quality accommodation for all Australian Defence Force personnel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question, which is entirely without notice. This Government has a great deal to be proud of in its record in providing adequate quality housing for the members of our Defence Force personnel. Some years ago my colleague the current Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), then Minister for Defence, announced a program worth some $750m to be expended over 10 years in upgrading the standard of housing provided to defence personnel through the Defence Housing Authority (DHA), which was created at that time. We are about a third of the way through that program, but rather more than a third of the way in making progress towards that laudable objective.

ANSWER.PARA: The report of the Cross committee, on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force, revealed that a major reason for people leaving the defence forces was the fact that the housing provided-not just the housing, but the standard of maintenance, the quality of the housing and the areas in which it was located-was not adequate.

The DHA has gone a long way towards changing all that. Two or three weeks ago the Prime Minister went to Sydney to open a housing development at Wattle Grove, the like of which I think people in the defence forces had not seen before. Indeed, one corporal was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying that he had to keep pinching himself because he might wake up to find it was all a dream. As the Prime Minister knows, the standard of that housing is superb. It is housing that no person would be unhappy to live in.

There is some way to go. It is the case that the Commonwealth-State housing agreement renegotiations with the State governments have been agreed to by all State governments except, I am sad to say, South Australia. I am having talks with the South Australian State Minister about that in the near future. Under that program, we are handing back half of the service housing to the States and DHA is accepting responsibility for the other half of it. I am pleased to say that the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, as one of his last acts agreed to an increase in the borrowing program for the Defence Housing Authority which will enable us to purchase a further couple of hundred houses in this year at a time when the housing market is not at its peak.

In short, I believe that the progress which has been made in giving Defence Force personnel decent housing-and no member of this House would dispute that is an entitlement they ought to have-has been very rapid in recent years. As a member of the Cross committee, I remember visiting a number of defence bases and establishments around the north of Australia and witnessing the slums in which defence personnel had to live. That is a shameful blot on the record of previous governments-it was a legacy of previous governments-and is a blot which we are a long way towards wiping out.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991[COGNATE BILLS:SOCIAL SECURITY (DISABILITY AND SICKNESS SUPPORT) AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) AMENDMENT BILL 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Mr Staples:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) concurrently with the Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill and the Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill. That being the case, the Chair will allow that course of action to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seem to make a repeat speech at this time of year, and I made it only last week, where again at the end of the parliamentary session legislation in connection with the aged and disadvantaged is being rushed through this House without any time for proper debate. Since I took over this portfolio over three years ago, we have never had the opportunity to debate as we should in the Parliament of Australia the requirements, needs and issues of people who are more disadvantaged than people here. We have not had debate with any degree of freedom because of the wretched timetables set by the guillotine.

SPEECH.PARA: We notice that when it comes to debating matters of social justice this Government denies the basic right of the members of this Parliament to be consulted and to speak. I have mentioned the guillotine. As an example of great laxity, I need only mention the particular Ministers responsible for this legislation, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and the Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), who is still basically in charge of the health and social portfolio. Over recent weeks, these people have been concerning themselves with their own welfare and power rather than those of their constituents out in the electorate, the aged and disadvantaged.

We can see this through the fact that the legislation now before us as the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill and the Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill was foreshadowed in the Budget nine months ago-that is, the 1990 Budget-and yet it was introduced into the Parliament only last Friday. It was introduced very much in a draft form; some haste is indicated by the Department of Social Security's not having been ready for what is contained in it.

There has been no time for consultation on or discussion of this very important package of reforms. The Minister for Social Security has spent time overseas on two extravagant trips that cost the Australian taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars; in the last week he was drumming up votes for the bid by the ex-Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), for the prime ministership; and over this year he has had excessive consultations with Mr Burke on his position over in Ireland. In the meantime, we have seen a $1m loss at the Ravenshoe sawmill, where money was incorrectly directed because the Minister had no supervision.

It is time the Minister and the Government started to look at the needs of people who are disadvantaged and let this House have its fair say. Those are just some of the examples where the Minister shows such disdain for the disadvantaged in our society.

Today we are debating, in great haste, three Bills, one of which is of major significance to people with disadvantages and to their families, yet we barely have two hours, I think it will be now, to discuss the whole package of Bills and put them through this House.

The Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill gives effect to changes announced in the 1990 Budget designed to restructure income support for the sick and the disabled. The Government concedes that for many years now the basis for, and operation of, invalid pensions and sickness benefits have not been satisfactory. The invalid pension will be replaced by a disability support pension and the sickness benefit will be replaced by a sickness allowance. The sheltered employment allowance will be abolished. The rehabilitation and incentive allowance, as well as the wife pension, will be phased out, and the mobility allowance increased from $22 to $40 a fortnight.

Whilst we welcome the increase in the mobility allowance, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) will recall that the Social Security Review Issues Paper No. 5, Enabling Policies for People with Disabilities, recommended that eligibility for the allowance be widened to include not only people with disabilities involved in employment or training but also those involved in family care, household work, community activities and Job Search.

Once again the Minister has chosen to ignore those particular recommendations. Indeed, the mobility allowance has already been withdrawn for those previously attending activity therapy centres in Western Australia and now participating in community access and support services. On behalf of people with disabilities, their carers and families and the service providers, we do ask the Minister to recognise the extra cost of disability and to re-examine widening the eligibility for the mobility allowance.

We are also concerned that payment for 16- to 20-year-olds will fall below single invalid pension rates. Payments for this group are now to be linked with the common youth allowance. They will also receive the equivalent of the child disability allowance, but they are still taking a drop in rates. We believe this is a harsh decision for young people with disabilities, particularly their parents and their families, and is contrary to the stated philosophy of Government legislation, which aims to assist people with disabilities integrate fully into the community. Again, this decision fails to recognise the extra cost of disabilities and overlooks the real needs of a person with disabilities-particularly in this young age group-which are education, training, transport and the need for outreach into an adult community.

Currently, in order to qualify for an invalid pension, a person must have a permanent-defined as 85 per cent-incapacity, of which at least one-half must be due to physical, mental or psychological impairment. In practice invalid pensions have been granted to persons with impairment levels as low as 15 per cent, leading to an extraordinary blow-out in the number of those receiving the invalid pension as either a pensioner or a wife or a carer.

In 1970-71 there were 150,000 recipients. In 1989-90, 20 years later, there were 413,000. This increase goes far beyond what might be explained by population growth. We believe the reason is not declining health standards but a progressive softening in the criteria determining eligibility. In many instances it has become a form of hidden unemployment, particularly for young people. With the number of people aged under 30 on invalid pensions in the mid-1990s being 34,000, that is in actual fact probably a degree of hidden unemployment.

Despite many invalid pensioners having only relatively minor physical injuries, only 2 per cent have been re-entering the labour market. The changes in this Bill are therefore clearly a political response to a system widely perceived as being completely out of control. Under amendments proposed in this Bill, in order to qualify for a disability support pension a person must have a physical, intellectual or psychiatric impairment of 20 per cent and a continuing inability to work for at least the next two years.

The explanatory memorandum states that the inability to work must stem completely, or virtually completely, from the impairment. Non-medical factors will not be taken into account except for those aged over 55 years. We find the fact that non-medical factors will not be taken into account extraordinary in view of the reaction of government bodies, advocates, medical bodies and service providers alike that an intellectual disability is not a medical condition. When I introduced a draft Bill some two years ago to amend the Disability Services Act-a discussion paper proposing amendments to the Disability Services Act-I was castigated for suggesting that a medical practitioner be consulted in determining the level of disability.

It would appear that this section of the Bill has been drafted without any consultation with the disability services program of the Department as to what constitutes an intellectual disability. This is only one example of the inconsistency in thinking between the Department of Social Security and the Department of Community Services and Health. When we were debating last week the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill, I pointed out that, on the one hand, one Minister was stating that jobs are universally available for people with disabilities and yet denying these people access to jobs in the Public Service and his own Department while, on the other hand, another Minister was making provision for a huge influx of able unemployed because jobs are just not available.

Whilst the Bill professes to introduce fundamental changes, a number of features suggest that the changes are in many respects largely cosmetic. People currently on invalid pensions will be automatically transferred to the disability support pension and will not be subject to any medical re-examination or reassessment. We find this extremely worrying. What chance will such people have for reassessment, retraining and an opportunity to lead a more fulfilling life in the community? What are the qualifications of the people who will be assessing them? Why are 75 new disability support officers (DSOs) being employed to do the job that experienced service providers could do at no extra cost to the taxpayer?

Again, we ask: what chances will these people have for rehabilitation and training? This would appear to be another example of inconsistency with the Disability Services Act under which sheltered workshops, which provide valuable training, living skills and social interaction, are being phased out by the Minister. Also, I point out to the Minister that if all those currently receiving invalid pensions chose to be active there would be insufficient disability support officers to deal with them all. Is the Government relying on the majority of current invalid pensioners to settle just for the unemployment scrap heap with no encouragement whatsoever from the Government for rehabilitation, training and education because the funds and the positions are not there to match those numbers if they were to apply in full force?

The 20 per cent impairment test merely legitimises the status quo and will continue to constitute a very low eligibility threshold. By introducing a two-year yardstick for inability to work, the concept of permanent incapacity has been effectively discarded. Under the definition of `continuing inability to work', a person will be entitled to a disability support pension even if capable of performing a range of work other than the person's usual work or work for which the person is currently skilled.

The changes are not estimated to achieve any savings for at least two years, and beyond that point are largely dependent upon the success of rehabilitation and training programs in encouraging people to re-enter the work force. The retention of non-medical factors such as age and the likelihood of finding work in the locally accessible labour market for those aged over 55 years simply makes it easier for this group to obtain a pension rather than joining the unemployment queues.

The Bill pins its hopes on streaming new entrants into training and rehabilitation programs with the initial engagement of 75 disability support officers, with the number doubling over the next two years. Those responsible for administering the previous regime will merely be absorbed elsewhere. The DSOs will determine the initial eligibility of an estimated 70,000 claimants per year, and then a joint panel of officers from the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service and the Department of Employment, Education and Training labour market training program will identify those who are to be placed in an active stream and required to participate in an additional 12,000 training places over the next three years, for which $10m has been allocated.

Despite the very poor track record of training and rehabilitation in weaning injured workers away from income support payments for workers compensation, invalid pensions and the like, the Bill relies heavily on this approach, casting a large question mark over future projected savings. The Bill effectively eschews several hard options: first, raising the eligibility high jump bar; secondly, tightening up on monitoring and reassessment; and, thirdly, forcing immediate participation in training programs and paid employment.

As a result, the incentive structure will remain largely unchanged. It will still be relatively attractive to seek and remain on a disability support pension which, unlike other pensions and benefits, will remain exempt from income tax. The crux of the Bill lies in the conditions which may be attached to the continuing entitlement to receive a disability support pension.

If the Secretary is satisfied that it will assist a person's ability to work, the Secretary may require such person to: receive treatment; complete a questionnaire; undertake a program of assistance or rehabilitation; or do, or apply for, paid work which, in the opinion of the Secretary, is suitable to be undertaken by that person. The Secretary must also take into account the plans, preferences, views and needs of the person and the capacity of the person to comply with the requirement. If stringently enforced, these provisions will have the potential to significantly tighten the regime over the longer term but a great deal will rest on the exercise of administrative discretion.

The penalties for non-compliance appear to be somewhat inadequate. Refusal to comply with a request in the first instance attracts only a warning. A second refusal will result in a two-week deferment and a third in a six-week deferment. It is only then that the Secretary must cancel the pension. Moreover, even the soft penalties for non-compliance will not come into operation until 1 October 1993, by which time the rehabilitation and labour market infrastructure is expected to be established. It should be noted that this date extends beyond the likely date of the next election and is further evidence of a refusal by this Government to bite the bullet.

The Opposition believes that the ability to impose mandatory conditions on individual recipients is important, particularly as it would seem to allow for the introduction of a work for the pension scheme on a case by case basis. However, I question whether the deferment regime is not too lax. I would be interested to hear from the Minister the rationale behind these rather weak penalties.

The portability of disability support pensions overseas will be limited to a maximum of 12 months for pensions granted after 30 June 1991, except for severely disabled persons and where a social security agreement with a foreign country provides otherwise. The coalition supports this proposal.

A sickness allowance will replace the sickness benefit for those who become incapacitated for work due to sickness or accident. Where the sickness or accident occasions absence from ongoing employment, the test will be an ability to perform the usual work. In other cases it will be work which the person could reasonably be expected to do. This approach seems reasonable, and the requirement to undertake work which the person could reasonably be expected to do is broader than the usual or currently qualified work test for the disability support pension.

The Bill proposes similar deferment periods in the event of refusal to cooperate. Again, we question whether these are not too lax. For recipients for whom rehabilitation is not deemed appropriate, the allowance will be payable for up to 13 weeks, after which fresh medical and other evidence will be required. A fresh claim must also be lodged after 12 months. Payments cannot continue beyond three years, except in respect of a new or significantly worsened medical condition. We support these provisions on sickness allowance.

However, we believe that the Government has looked at disability reform in a piecemeal fashion and has not heeded the recommendations of its own review committee on a disability allowance or the widening of the eligibility criteria for the mobility allowance. It has not recognised the extra costs of disability. We shall be moving a second reading amendment regretting the failure of the Government to undertake a fundamental overhaul of the present system.

I turn to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). This Bill implements some relatively minor policy changes and allows for the amendments made to the 1947 Social Security Act during the 1991 autumn sittings to be incorporated into the plain-English 1991 Social Security Act. Change to eligibility criteria for special benefits is also a part of this package. This Bill allows for special benefits to be payable, at the discretion of the Secretary of the Department of Social Security, to a person who is the holder of a conditional two-year residence permit granted on the basis of a relationship with an Australian resident where the application for that payment was made on or after 15 April 1991.

Under the recently introduced migration rules, as from 15 April 1991, a two-year conditional residence permit can be granted to a person who has entered into a formal marriage or de facto relationship with an Australian citizen or resident. The proposed change would allow special benefits to be paid to such persons and, if necessary, backdated to the commencement date of the new rules. It must be presumed that applicants for such conditional entry permits and, indeed, the overwhelming proportion of migrants to this country are able-bodied citizens who are entering Australia with adequate means of support. To allow newly arrived migrants immediately to receive social security income support sends precisely the wrong signals to prospective entrants.

There is even less justification for any retrospective operation. While the Department of Social Security may have promised such payments as from 1 April 1991, it had no authority to do so. Presuming the new arrivals have survived financially to date, there is no justification for now providing them with a backdated lump sum payment. The Opposition cannot support the changes proposed in clauses 4 and 10.

The Bill also provides for the indexation of income free areas of pensions and benefits where the income is derived from child support or maintenance. Indexation will occur on 1 July each year. This measure will ensure that the allowable level of child support is not eroded over time by inflation. Such an erosion makes child support a relatively unattractive source of income over time, leading to informal arrangements between separated parents to evade or reduce child support payments so as to permit more of the burden to be picked up by the state. We support this initiative.

The pharmaceutical allowance is to be indexed from the first pension or benefit payday after 20 September each year. The allowance is paid to pensioners and some beneficiaries to compensate them for the concessional beneficiary charge which applies per pharmaceutical item and currently stands at $2.50.

Indexation will mean that pensioners will be protected from increases in the pharmaceutical beneficiary charge. We shall not oppose this initiative. However, the annual cost of indexation of the allowance to rises in the charge is high. Is this really indicative of the increases in the charge that the Government has in store for the next and subsequent Budgets? The Bill also adds further refinements to the restrictions on the portability of the wife's and class B widow's pensions which were put in place last year, and we support this initiative.

I will deal now with pharmaceutical benefits card eligibility. Pensioners were promised that they would not lose entitlement to the pharmaceutical benefits card if, as a result of complying with the initiative to deem a rate of return on their savings above designated savings thresholds, the rearranging of their assets pushed their incomes above the income thresholds which determine eligibility for the card. Pensioners who lost entitlement to the pension as a result of deeming will lose entitlement to the pharmaceutical benefits card.

It appears that if one had these arrangements in place prior to the change of deeming one would retain one's card whereas people who played the game and were investing their money properly would be denied that card. However, we support the provision. We also support the reciprocal social security agreement with the Netherlands.

I turn now to the incorporation of measures in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 into the Social Security Act 1991. Measures in this Bill, such as excluding approved scholarships from the definition of income for income test purposes, the exemption of certain funeral bond moneys from pension income and assets tests and the confirmation of the primacy of Commonwealth legislation in relation to recovery of overpayments from compensation lump sums which were included in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, will be incorporated into the new plain-English Social Security Act 1991 by this Bill.

Also incorporated into the plain-English Act via this Bill are the policy and technical initiatives and changes in this particular Bill. Featured amongst the transitional arrangements in this Bill is clause 20, which is designed to exempt the Secretary's power to waive a debt from review by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT). The Opposition still opposes this particular provision.

The Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill contains no policy changes. It proposes a number of amendments to the plain-English Social Security Act 1991 before it commences operation on 1 July 1991. It also incorporates the transitional arrangements to the old Social Security Act 1947 which were passed during the 1990 Budget sittings. Among the initiatives which this Bill incorporates into the 1991 Social Security Act are those which relate to the liquid assets test for sickness beneficiaries, disaster relief payments, deeming on loans and deposits, the reciprocal agreements between Malta and the United Kingdom and the provision of tax file numbers. The changes involve minor tidying up of existing legislation to make the intent of the legislation clearer and minor drafting changes to tighten up the new Act before it comes into operation. The Bill should mean fewer appeals to the SSAT and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, resulting in savings for both the Department of Social Security and its clients. We support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a particular interest in the Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill 1991. I take the point made by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) that this is a cognate debate on more than one Bill; in fact, two other social security Bills are also under consideration. I had the pleasure of being involved in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in May 1988 when we brought down a report called Getting to Work. That was a report of the inquiry of that Committee into the entry or return to the work force of social security pensioners and beneficiaries. One of the groups of people with whom we had discussions were people with disabilities. Many of the points which are covered in the Bill today were also raised at that time by people with disabilities and by representatives of those people.

SPEECH.PARA: I inform the House that one page in the report, where we outlined the recommendations and information provided by the Office of Disability, indicated that in May 1988 at least 461,000 people were receiving social security benefits because of disability. These 461,000 people comprised 292,000 people on the invalid pension, 11,418 people on the sheltered employment allowance, 6,300 people in receipt of the rehabilitation allowance, 87,214 people receiving the wife's pension-a pension for the wife of an invalid-6,500 people receiving a carer's pension, 1,768 people receiving special benefit, and 71,019 people receiving sickness benefits.

The point that was made by the Office of Disability at that time-it was taken on board by the Committee and since then by the Government-was that people with disabilities are just as interested in paid employment as are people who are not disabled. During consultations conducted by the Office of Disability in 1987 disabled adults identified the loss of employment income and opportunities as a high priority concern. Largely, that is what this Bill is about and what the Government's changes in this area have been about all along.

It has already been indicated in the second reading speech of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) that this is an undertaking that was made in the 1990-91 Budget. It was also the result of an extensive review of income support and other forms of assistance for the disabled. That was part of the Social Security Review which produced a great number of very substantial and valuable reports for the Government. It implements further significant reforms to the Australian social security system and to the pension aspects of that system.

From my own experience, I understand well and truly that many people who are disabled wish to work and they were confronting a great many barriers in the workplace in order to do so, not least of which was their fear of losing access to the invalid pension. When people may have been 85 per cent incapacitated, for instance, and have been in receipt of an invalid pension, it is strange to think that they could work. But people can work and they work at things that they like doing but they must not have pressure placed upon them where they think that they will lose that income support if they work for a few short years on a part time basis for a few hours a week. The very act of working and being involved in the social interaction at work is beneficial to their health in most cases.

In May 1988, the House of Representatives Standing Committee was concerned that people in those circumstances were not taking up opportunities that may have been available to them, even sometimes for voluntary work, because they were afraid that they would lose their invalid pension. This legislation is attempting to overcome that fear and to overcome the stigma of disability in our society, as well as to change the way that we have tended to institutionalise disability in the past.

The Minister in his second reading speech pointed out that there was a small but significant percentage of cases of relatively young people, even people in their twenties, who were not manifestly impaired but who were being awarded the invalid pension with the expectation that they would continue to receive it on an indefinite basis. The concept of permanent incapacity for work became self-fulfilling and only some 2 per cent of invalid pensioners went off the pension because of their return to employment. This is not because these people did not want to work; many of them would like to work but were genuinely afraid that if they undertook any work at all it would bring about the loss of what was an essential income support for them and exacerbate the difficulties that they were having. For instance, people who have very severe asthma may not want to take up work despite its advantages because the stress of not working would be less than the stress of working and fearing the loss of their pension.

The main features of the changes that we are discussing today are the reform of income support arrangements for persons with disabilities to remove existing anomalies and encourage greater participation in the labour market and to change the sickness benefit which will now be re-named sickness allowance and be limited to 12 months duration except under special conditions.

This package of assistance measures totals $48.6m in 1991-92 and will increase to $88m in 1993-94 to encourage people with disabilities to realise their labour force potential. Critics may think that this is an inappropriate time to bring in this type of legislation which will encourage more people to try to attain training or employment. There is never a correct time; this time is as good as any other when we have labour market packages available for people through Skillshare and technical and further education colleges and a lot of other organisations in our society. Disabled people should be able to access those types of training and assistance.

Certainly that is the sort of thing that I would like to see happening, although some of the Skillshare projects have not been assisting these people because, obviously, they are a little difficult to assist. Fairly specialised personnel and sometimes specialised equipment are needed to help them in some circumstances. Nevertheless, with the change to the Skillshare guidelines and module funding packages there is now specific funding for the assistance of people with disabilities through Skillshare as an avenue of training.

The Bill continues the development of a common allowance structure for income support given to young people. This will be done by aligning the rates of disability support pension for people under 21 with the rates of Job Search and Newstart allowance payable to people under 21. It may appear that I am concentrating my remarks on young people. While that is not true, it is still important to recall that young people can adopt a mindset of disability if they are not careful and if we as a community do not take every opportunity that we can to help them to break out of their disability in some way and to ensure that society is a sufficiently caring place to take their specific disability on board and assist them with employment and training.

The active stream, which will apply to new applicants only if they are able to work, will allow people to participate in training programs. I think it is important at this juncture to point out to people on the existing invalid pension that they will not have to undergo any difficult transition with the change brought about by this legislation because they will simply be changed over to the new allowance or the new pension, as the case may be, but it will not be called the invalid pension any longer. Their situation will not be reviewed until such time as a normal review falls due for them in a few years or something like that. In the main this legislation is aimed at new applicants for the invalid pension or for disability support.

A couple of recommendations made in the booklet Getting to Work are quite pertinent to this discussion. It is indicated on page 73 of the booklet that the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training had received submissions from some organisations that had received funding from the Department of Community Services and Health for demonstration projects to establish the employability of people with disabilities, because the Committee saw that it might not appear to be a worthwhile thing to employ people with disabilities at a time when other people were seeking work. It was clear that the additional assistance provided by the specialist advisory services was essential to gain employment for many of these people, and the organisations' submissions suggested a high success rate with the ongoing funding being important.

Evidence to that effect was also given by advocacy groups such as the Commonwealth Office for Disability, the Disability Advisory Council of Australia and the Disability Council of New South Wales. All of these groups emphasised the waste of human resources if disabled people are ignored as potential work force participants. I certainly agree with that. The comparative economic disadvantage suffered by disabled people is dramatic, as:
- only 40% are employed, versus an Australian average of 70%
- the unemployment rate amongst the disabled is double the community average-
which is not surprising-
- the average household incomes are one-third lower than the Australian average

Barriers to employment are experienced not only by invalid pensioners but also by beneficiaries who may have an unrecognised disability. Of course many employers do not appreciate the sort of assistance and work output that a disabled person is capable of achieving, because they cannot see past the disability. However, many of these people have useful skills that we could utilise in our work force.
The recommendations of the Committee included the following:
Additional assistance should be provided to assist disabled people on pensions or benefits to gain access to employment. Principles which should be followed include:
- discouragement of discrimination in all areas of employment and training
- specific provision for inclusion of disabled people in government training and job creation programs
- pilot projects by specialist advocacy and job training organisations to assist disabled people gain employment should be continued at 100% funding level
- part-time work opportunities should be encouraged
- programs to persuade employers to favourably consider the employability of disabled people should be introduced.

That is actually a very good outcome; this legislation picks up most of the recommendations of the report in one way or another. I think anybody involved in that Committee would be pleased to see that the Government has undertaken extensive consultations in the community with disabled people, with disabled people's advocacy groups and with the parents of young disabled people to ascertain their views on these types of reform. I would say they are very acceptable to the majority of disabled people in this country and that we, as a government and a parliament, can be pleased to accept them. I therefore commend the legislation to the House and thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), who is at the table and who is representing the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), and our own Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services for the outcome that we see here today. I hope that all aspects of this legislation will be carried when it goes to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which is one of three important social security Bills to be debated in this place this afternoon. I take the opportunity, as I will do whenever I speak in circumstances such as these, to castigate the Government for the way in which it has treated this Parliament by applying the guillotine not only to discussion of this legislation but also to discussion on a great number of other very important Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe I was elected by my constituents to come here and do a job; I am here to participate in the democratic process and I think the Government has acted despicably by acting in this way, to say nothing of its sheer ineptitude and inability to get legislation into this place. This Parliament will not and cannot work, and democracy cannot work, unless we are given adequate opportunity to debate properly these propositions, some of which are extremely important.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can have five minutes of my time.

—I will take the time of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro if I can get a chance to do so. We had the farce yesterday afternoon of having an important piece of environmental legislation coming up for debate and finding that the time for debate on that Bill had actually expired before it even commenced. What sort of democracy is that? I want to put on record my protest once again at the way in which this Government treats this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation raises a number of interesting and important issues. In reading between the lines on what the Government proposes, one cannot help making the observation that Australia is fast becoming one of the world's great welfare states. I assume that is the Government's intention.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish-absolute rubbish.

—The honourable member for Cowan protests. All the do-gooders on the Government side are into giving handouts to everybody; it is a free lunch for everybody in this country; people can come here from all over the world, go on the unemployment benefit the day they walk in, and when they have been here 10 years they can get onto the age pension. It really is terrific, but the only problem Australia has as it heads further down the Argentinean road along which the failed Treasurer and honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) took Australia is that it cannot afford it any longer. We have fewer taxpayers; businesses are going broke every day; people are finding it very difficult to pay their taxes. Even the Government's temporary solution to the problem has become an enormous debt because it has borrowed extensively overseas to prop up so many of its great programs and has sent this country into near insolvency.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before us further cements the approach that we have seen this Government take. The House is considering the situation in which a two-year conditional residence permit can be granted to a person who has entered into a formal marriage or a de facto relationship with an Australian citizen or resident. After the debate we had on immigration last night, when I had an altercation with the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), I would also assume that homosexual relationships were included in this. In other words, a homosexual who gets connected up with a homosexual in some other country can, now that we have provided this special treatment, bring that person here as a homosexual partner under the same terms.

It came home to me in talking about the issue of the two-year conditional residence permit last night-we are talking here about immigration to some extent, although strictly speaking it is the social security aspects of it, but the two are very closely related-that when we consider the costs and benefits of immigration, we are quick to recognise the benefits. There have been enormous benefits for this country over the years. There is no doubt that, had we not had the immigration programs of the 1950s, we would not have had the burst of economic growth Australia had during those years. However, the 1990s present very different economic circumstances, and Australia is now saddled with a huge social security bill which is increasing every day as more people go on the unemployment benefit. I think we need to be much more critical of how the Government performs, and the Government needs to be more concerned about the way it spends taxpayers' money.

On the 60 Minutes program a couple of weeks ago, we saw two lesbians living together. Each had a child. In the course of that particular program, it transpired that each of them was on a pension. One of them had the gall to say, `Well, actually, no matter how much the Government gives us, it is not enough; but we only get $800 a fortnight'. The reaction to that program from the public was absolute outrage. One of the letters that was broadcast suggested that, if they want to enter into that type of relationship, that is, to some extent, up to them, but at least one of them ought to assume the role of a breadwinner and go out to work. No, that would be too hard! Of course, we allow them, in effect, to live together, earning $800 a fortnight. We saw them going fishing. That is what they did; they went fishing. Why should they go to work when they can put their hands out!

The scenario that I am creating here in dealing with this particular legislation is that once again we are confronted with an attempt to create handouts, but we are not even talking, in this situation, about handouts for Australian citizens. We want to go way beyond that now. We want to make it more attractive for people to come here from overseas, land on our shores and put their hands out-put their hands out from the moment they arrive here. This legislation which we are confronted with this afternoon makes it possible for people who have come here, on a conditional residence permit-that is, those who are in a de facto relationship or a formal marriage or, I assume, some sort of homosexual marriage or relationship, whatever they call them-to become entitled to a special benefit, which is actually going to be backdated, would honourable members believe, to the commencement date of the new rules.

When these people arrive here under those circumstances, there is not even any guarantee that they will be able-bodied people. That is why there is the crossover in this area with the immigration rules. In most situations, we would expect when they come here that they would be able to earn something or go out to work. I suppose that would depend on their being able to get a job, and that came out during the 60 Minutes program last Sunday. What an informative program 60 Minutes is! Last Sunday, we saw an Indian couple who had arrived here expecting that they would be able to get a job. They were interviewed. They seemed to me to be extremely articulate, sensible, decent people. They said that they arrived here, could not get a job and felt very bad, having been here only a short time, because they had to go down and get on the end of the queue for unemployment benefit.

We have encouraged these people; we have allowed these people to come here and we have told them that they can get a job. Of course, they arrive here and find that they cannot get a job and so they get on the unemployment queue. There has to be something dramatically wrong with the way that we handle these particular situations. I believe that the people of Australia are entitled to be extremely cynical about the payment of social security benefits to people who have just arrived here under any circumstances; yet, time after time, we see examples of people who come to this country and immediately get on the line for handouts.

At least we require people to live here for 10 years-and even that does not seem a long time-before they can get the age pension. The anomaly in that situation is that they can actually come here and get unemployment benefit pretty much the day they arrive. They can stay on unemployment benefit for 10 years, even given the new Jobstart and Job Search arrangements that are in place; then, after 10 years, they can get the age pension. So they get unemployment benefit or some derivation of it for 10 years, then they get the age pension.

I believe that to allow newly arrived immigrants immediately to receive any social security income support certainly sends precisely the wrong signals to prospective entrants. I am sure that the word has got out. It is no wonder that people want to come here! It is no wonder that this is such a marvellous country for people to come to! We maintain the biggest immigration program in the world; on a per capita basis, it is three times the size of the immigration program of the United States. It is no wonder that people want to come here! The word has spread, I imagine, that if people cannot get a job in Australia, it is okay because they get handouts. They can actually come here and live comfortably without having to do any work. For people in most countries of the world, that is quite a surprise. There are not many countries-in fact, I think we are probably the only country-that make that type of facility available to people.

I have a letter, coincidentally, as this matter came up today, from one of my constituents who lives in Surfers Paradise. He asked me a couple of rather pertinent questions, and in framing a reply I found it rather difficult. He said:

Is it permissible for an Australian resident, NOT citizen, whose only income is the Government pension (age) supplemented by a small age pension from another country, who lives in a Housing Commission residence also subsidised, of course, by public monies to be regarded by the immigration authorities as an acceptable husband-to-be for the national of another country.

The answer to that is yes, under the present rules. We do not want to interfere if somebody chooses to marry someone who is living overseas. We do not want to question that. They can make that choice, apparently. If they want to bring their husband, wife or homosexual partner here now, it is okay; and, of course, the implication is that they can then get some social security. The writer of the letter went on and made the point that, I believe, most Australians would make:

To me as a taxpayer, in receipt of no largesse from the Government at all, it is of the utmost concern that this country should not be saddled with any more social security recipients than we have already. To contemplate the admission of a person with no acceptable qualification, other than that of prospective bride, to join in matrimony a person already receiving social security income defies belief!
And it does defy belief. The writer went on:
It is obvious that a single pension will almost immediately be converted to a married pension for a person who has not contributed in any way to the funds of this country.

He then asked a question, which I have now to answer. Maybe the Government members when they speak can help me. I will probably write to the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) or the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), because I need to answer this question:
Are we admitting people with no income to join a person-
not necessarily even Australian; we are talking here about not only Australian citizens but also people who are just resident here-
(not Australian) only in receipt of Social Security??
The answer is `Yes, we are'. Under this legislation, that is exactly what we propose to do, and I think it is outrageous.

I could talk about the rorts in the immigration system because they impinge on this, but I talked about that last night. The Government, under the guillotine, rammed through some very significant legislation, some of which I have already alluded to. I got the impression from some of the Government members who were contributing in that debate last night that it is almost laissez faire as far as immigration is concerned. Anyone can come; just about anything goes. We have got 150,000 illegal immigrants in Australia; people have come here on holidays or have come as students and do not want to be students any more. They are out there taking jobs. In my electorate alone, there are hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people working illegally who are taking jobs from young Australians. They are the types of jobs that they are doing. They are taking jobs from young Australians. We have encouraged them to come here. Of course, now that they are here, we cannot find them because we have not got the money to put into programs to find them. It is a big country. If we really started looking closely at my electorate, which I guess lends itself to people who want to come and live the life of Riley--

TALK.START.PARA: —The tourism capital of Australia.

—It is the tourism capital of Australia, as the honourable member for Fadden said. We find an awful lot of them hanging around there. I say to employers-I will not get too far off the track here-that they should not be employing them; but they are being employed sometimes in substandard conditions, on below award wages, and so on. So we need to question the benefits of an immigration program that has gone just so far out of control. We need to look at what the actual down side is, and to add into the costs of our immigration program, when we do that exercise, the costs of the welfare that we hand out because, for practical purposes, where a migrant never works in Australia, it would be correct to charge the permanent ongoing costs to the cost of immigration. We would then have a far better idea of how our taxes are being swelled by the immigration program.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, it appears to me that there are no serious procedures to stop sponsored migrants or even illegal immigrants, as I said before, from claiming unemployment or other benefits immediately on arrival. But the position gets worse-if that is possible. This legislation actually goes beyond that position. Not only are we going to allow people to come here and to go on social security straight away-and if the husband is already on a pension and brings his new wife here, then they get the married pension overnight-but the Government proposes to be even more generous.

We are talking here about being generous with taxpayers' money; it must be easy if the Government is not spending its own money, because it has decided that new arrivals are entitled to backdated lump sum payments. The Department of Social Security apparently has promised payments as from 1 April 1991. I hope somebody on the Government side will answer this question in the limited time available for the debate: assuming new arrivals have survived financially to date, what justification is there for this back payment now to 1 April 1991? It is just Government largess again. No wonder the great majority of taxpayers listening to this debate today are concerned about how their money is being spent.

I turn briefly to a couple of aspects of this legislation. First, the indexation of the pharmaceutical allowance: last year the Government introduced the concessional beneficiary pharmaceutical charge, which was designed to arrest the explosion in the cost of so-called free pharmaceuticals. The Government gives the wrong message in many respects because people, if they do not pay for something, think it is free. So the Government's response in respect of the pharmaceutical benefits was to introduce a charge.

That was okay; that was in a sense using a price mechanism for what, I suppose, is a fairly valid purpose. But then the Government had to compensate the pensioners. It came up with a scheme whereby the pensioners got more money. Although they had to pay when they went to get their prescriptions, they were not really paying because they were getting the money back on their pensions. Nevertheless, it has probably had some psychological effect because people having to put their hands in their pocket when they went to a pharmacy had the immediate effect of deterring them from getting prescriptions unnecessarily. I do not know whose fault it was.

When pensioners or anybody else go to the doctor, the doctor says, `What is wrong?'. They say, `I have got a headache'. The doctor says, `I will give you a prescription'. That was okay. But now the pensioner says, `Hang on. Can you do something else? I do not want a prescription because it costs me $2.50'. It does not really cost them that but they have to fork out $2.50 when they get a prescription.

That is one of the problems we have with the whole Medicare system. No wonder it is costing this country so much: people think it is free as well. They pay a Medicare levy, but the total levy collections work out to be about one-fifth of the actual cost of running the whole scheme. Of course, we have bulkbilling, whereby even wealthy people say, `This is terrific; we can go to the doctor for nothing'. But that is not true either. It is costing a lot more than that.

In this situation the Minister has upset a lot of people. As I said, his idea was right about putting the charge on. But he has upset a lot of people and so he has had to increase the pensions. But in the process-and talk about compounding errors, or going from the sublime to the ridiculous-he effectively overcompensates many pensioners because there is a vast number out there who did not need so many prescriptions. So these people are effectively overcompensated. We now find that this overcompensation will be entrenched by this Bill. I suppose that must be, in a sense, an unintended consequence. I am not making a statement here about the plight of pensioners because they have certainly got plenty to complain about, but it is hardly the best way to solve a problem which the Minister created for himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to oppose the amendment put forward by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) which, while not declining to give the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) a second reading, expresses regret at the Government's failure to undertake a fundamental overhaul of the whole system for the payment of disability and sickness support benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), who has just spoken, has indicated quite dramatically how those opposite are in utter confusion. First of all, for seven years they had a much higher social security budget than this Government has had in its first seven years-much higher because they had more handouts and more unemployment benefits. Now the honourable member is accusing us of not remedying the situation which was left as a legacy by the previous Government.

What the honourable member has said when talking about migrants is that we have not taken actions which were not taken when those opposite were in government. In fact, actions have been taken. With regard to migration, for instance, of over one million applicants-I do not know what the exact figure is because I did not expect to come here to debate migration-little more than 100,000 are permitted to come to Australia. Because of the substantial checking through the points system, these migrants are targeted so that there is not much likelihood of them being unemployed.

It certainly happens in the case of refugees, but under United Nations arrangements and other international arrangements we take a certain proportion of refugees into Australia. If these refugees are entitled to benefits, then it may well be that they ought to receive them. After all, they have to live. We have taken them under an international agreement and we ought to allow them to have benefits in those cases. But people who are assessed under normal migration criteria are assessed so thoroughly that there is not much chance that a substantial number of them will be unemployed.

It is no wonder that there is confusion because under the previous Government the number of handouts was substantially higher. Now those opposite are saying, `Let us get tougher. Let us take unemployment benefits off people after nine months'.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good idea.

—The honourable member for McPherson says it is a good idea. If we take unemployment benefits off people after nine months, what we will get is what we see in the United States: people queuing at soup kitchens and sleeping under scaffolding. I would like to go to New York with the honourable member for McPherson; he is good company. I am on a couple of committees with him. If he went to New York with me and just walked along the streets, he would see sleeping under scaffolding people who have nowhere to sleep, no public housing and no benefits. They are begging for money. Those people hang up their clothes, if it is raining, on scaffolding, and try to sleep under it.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite are talking tough. The confusion is that we do not know whether they would be tough or whether they would go back to their old ways of being careless and saying, `We can push these people aside, on the dole, and forget about them'. What we are trying to do now through this legislation is to have a fundamental overhaul of what applies to people. The broad range of social security, employment, education and training measures is going to give accountability to taxpayers-the sort of accountability which the honourable member for McPherson was requesting.

More than that, it is going to give fulfilment to Australians who have been forgotten. It is going to give maximum fulfilment to people who have been unemployed, perhaps long term, or to people who are disabled-or even to people who are in employment but who have not felt fulfilment. So through a broad range of training schemes and social security measures there is going to be encouragement for people who feel hopeless: we are going to give them hope through the legislation.

I thoroughly support the Government's legislation. Whatever the Government decides, I will not be voting for this amendment circulated by the honourable member for Dawson. He wants a fundamental overhaul but he will not tell us what that fundamental overhaul is.

The argument that the Opposition has so far put to us, the kite that it has flown, is assessment by charities-assessment of all these social security beneficiaries by charitable organisations and non-government organisations. Of course, the response we receive from the non-government organisations is that they do not want to do that. I certainly believe that they should not be able to do it, because those charitable and non-government organisations vary. One charitable organisation in one area may be generous; another charitable organisation in another area may be tough. Naturally, they do not want that because it gives them a whole new range of responsibilities. The assessment should be where it is, although maybe more localised, and that is in the area of government.

The Opposition then talked about payment by chartered accountants-for example, Price Waterhouse-instead of by the social security office. The honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) has said that there would be people walking into the marble halls of Price Waterhouse to talk about their payment of benefits. It is quite ridiculous to expect private organisations to handle this sort of thing in an equitable way. We should reject the sort of fundamental overhauls which the Opposition has talked about but which it has not defined. We do not want what has happened in other countries of the world: people pushing their worldly goods around in shopping trolleys, people being put out of institutions, because they cannot get benefits.

I strongly support the broad range of social security and economic measures, having had a fairly full involvement with them in committee, that have been instituted by the Government. The Government, through this legislation, is giving people greater fulfilment: for instance, the replacement of the invalid pension by the disability support pension, and the sickness benefit by the sickness allowance. With the implementation of these changes, people will have opportunities to look for work and will be encouraged to look for work.

What is the Opposition response? We had it from the honourable member for Dawson that the Opposition is worried that the people who are already on invalid pensions, the people who are already on benefits, are not being reassessed. He says that they will not be given the chance to receive rehabilitation and training. Those people certainly will receive those opportunities, if they want them. They will be encouraged, just as anyone will be, to take opportunities in rehabilitation and training with the broad range of measures that are being introduced and that are occurring already not only in hospitals where people are being rehabilitated but also in the Commonwealth rehabilitation centres. I had the privilege of opening one of these centres recently in Batemans Bay where people can get help with the transitional stages of being rehabilitated into the community, into their social life and then into work.
