Current recipients will be reviewed. All people who are on sickness benefit as at 30 September 1991 will be reviewed for continuous sickness allowance on or before 1 January 1992. Administratively, they cannot be processed any faster than over a three-month period, but they will be reviewed. Those who are on an invalid pension either now or at 30 September 1991 will be granted the disability support pension automatically on 1 October 1991. About 2 per cent of those on invalid pension as at 20 August 1990-which is the date of the announcement of the reforms-will be reviewed as soon as possible after 1 October 1991 as regards continued eligibility for the new pension. Of those granted invalid pension after 20 August 1990, 30 per cent will be reviewed as soon as possible after 1991.

So there has been a broad range of measures which will help not only the people who will be on benefits but also those who have been on benefits in the past. The opportunity is there. Of course, we do not want to be harsh on people, particularly those people who are over 55. They will be excepted from the consideration only of medical criteria. They will find it difficult to get back into work, just as unemployed people over the age of 55 will find it difficult to get back into work. We should not have the same expectations of those people. There will not be jobs for many of them. So it is pointless to place those strict requirements on them.

Other provisions will also be of benefit to people. For instance, those who find work will only have their pension suspended for two years, usually. But there is, as I have said, every chance for people to receive rehabilitation and training, if they really want it.

The Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill 1991 refers to amendments made to the 1947 Act by a number of pieces of legislation-the Social Welfare (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Act 1990, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1990, and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act 1990. There is a requirement that they be incorporated into the 1991 Act. This covers a wide range of initiatives that have been introduced, including the tax file number.

I say again that I disagreed with the withdrawal by this Government of the original proposal for an Australia Card. People come to me and say, `This tax file number is a nuisance. Why didn't you go ahead with the Australia Card?'. I have to say to them that we did not go ahead with the Australia Card because the Senate was obviously going to reject it. This Government introduced the proposal for an Australia Card. People are now saying, `We've got a drivers licence with our picture on it. Why can't we have an Australia Card? It would be much easier than this clerical or administrative work involving a tax file number'. With the Australia Card, people would just have had to show it; now they have to give their tax file number. That is recorded and available to banks, the Australian Taxation Office and Social Security. I agree that an Australia Card would have been much simpler. But now we have the tax file number. The tax file number is eliminating quite a deal of fraud but, more than that, it is making us accountable to the taxpayers, which the honourable member for McPherson was requesting.

Another initiative which is covered is deeming. There is no doubt that since deeming was introduced people have actually increased their incomes; it is no longer an advantage for them to invest for little or no return at all. They are now deemed to have a percentage return. Many people are finding that they are actually at an advantage by being able to invest in the wide range of opportunities available, even at call, in banks and other financial institutions. It is actually worth their while investing, and the deeming has had that benefit both for them and for taxpayers. In that the taxpayers are no longer obliged to support them to the same extent; they are doing better because they lose only 50c in every extra dollar that most of them make. The people who have lost, of course, are the banks and the financial institutions, who are paying no interest at all or, in some cases, very little interest on cheque accounts.

Other items include the liquid assets test for sickness beneficiaries and the recovery of overpayments. I am pleased that the methods used by the Department have to date, in my experience, been fairly elastic. Where there have been overpayments, the Department has been fairly flexible in the way that it has tolerated the repayments from clients who have been overpaid.

The employment entry payment for sole parents is extremely important. A couple of years ago, when we decided that sole parents whose children came of age would have to go back into the work force and be available for work for an income from the Government, I can remember people coming to me with very sad stories: women with very little or no employment at all since they had left school and some women with no employment since they were perhaps 19 or 20 years old, when they were married. They were very worried. But now, with the training schemes that are available, half of the people who have taken up these schemes have found jobs. It is very interesting that many employers throughout Australia, particularly those in small business, prefer these women who are coming back into the work force; they are very popular with employers.

Disaster relief payments are another area which is covered in the initiatives under the legislation. These payments are very important. They have different criteria. There can be problems where people are not always eligible for payments under other systems. As disasters are always a possibility in most areas of Australia, these payments are important.

Another initiative is the extension of the qualification criteria for remote area allowance. I, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls), the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil), and a wide range of other members would have people in our electorates who are entitled to a remote area allowance. Their extension of qualification needs to be taken into account, and it is.

The pharmaceutical benefits allowance, which is a charge, of course, is compensated. The honourable member for McPherson has referred to it. He does not realise that people are getting an allowance, so full funding is provided for their pharmaceutical benefits. He accuses us of overcompensating. He should realise-he may be listening to this speech in his office or somewhere else-that there has been a drop in the numbers of prescriptions to people who do not really need them. That will be both a financial benefit and a health benefit.

Sometimes people receive prescriptions which are worth anything up to $100 or $200. I think the highest priced item I have seen on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme was $1,700. People can get these benefits and not know that they are worth that amount. It is important that people are aware-not necessarily of the amount charged-of the fact that it costs money. That is why the charge is made on pharmaceutical benefits. The Government has supplemented pensions and other allowances so that people can afford to pay them. When they reach a threshold, they can then get free prescriptions. The amended international social security agreement with the United Kingdom and the new agreement with Malta are specifically mentioned.

The Budget 1990 initiatives which affect the employment benefit and Job Search allowance structure in the 1947 Act are incorporated into the new provisions for Job Search allowance and Newstart allowance to be inserted into the 1991 Act by the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, which was introduced into this House on 18 April 1991. That will mean, once again, that unemployment benefits are abolished. The concept of the dole has gone, but there is an allowance in its place.

The Government is not pulling out unemployment benefits after nine months, let alone immediately, but it is making sure that people can get an allowance, as long as they are prepared to enter an agreement with the Commonwealth Employment Service to undertake training schemes, if they are reasonably offered, and perhaps even move away if accommodation is reasonably offered. In other words, there should be a reasonable agreement. It may even cover the presentation of a person when going for a job. There is an agreement, which can be appealed against and can be reviewed, between the recipient of the allowance and the Commonwealth Employment Service and people are encouraged to go into the work force and are given all the means possible to assist them in the work force.

Unemployment is fairly high and it may get a little higher, but in six or seven months the turn is going to happen and people will need to be ready for the jobs as they come up. Honourable members should remember that the last time jobs came up there was a huge gap between the number of unemployed people and the number of employers who wanted people to work for them but could not find people with the right skills.

Under this legislation, which is a partner of the other legislation, we will find that people will be able to move into the work force more readily through the broad range of government programs. I oppose the Opposition's amendment and support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill and the Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill under discussion touch the lives of people who, while having so much to offer our society, are often cut off from the mainstream of Australia by a virtual glass wall. That is, people with physical, intellectual or emotional disabilities and people who are sick can see the mainstream of people and be seen, but in the past they could not join the mainstream because of lack of options and lack of opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people, including some honourable members in this House, appear to be absorbed by the abuses of the system which supports and rehabilitates people. This waste of taxpayers' money really worries them. That is fair enough, as long as we do not use this worry to cover up the greater worry and the greater need of people who have been neglected and from whom healthy society has turned away.

One has to look at such abuses of the system, because cheats are denying people with authentic needs the taxpayer funded aids and supports which are their right, or should be their right in a decent nation, and taking away the money which would go further to fill real needs in our society.

This Government is taking the anomalies and the adverse aspects of the social security system seriously, and is particularly looking at abuse. The Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill 1991 deals with such potential abuse. This Bill would include the provision for the deferment of disability support pension payments for relevant persons, who do not take reasonable steps to meet the active requirements of the pension, to receive treatment, undergo a program of assistance or undertake Job Search and work. These segments must be implemented with extreme sensitivity. A stigma could certainly attach to people during the process of monitoring and the process of assessment, but it is up to us to see that such a stigma does not arise and does not develop. It is the risk with any publicly funded program, but it is a risk which must be taken.

The Bill provides real hope and assistance for people in this category who are disabled or sick to acquire skills so that they will be better placed now and when the labour market starts to improve. To encourage transition to work, a disability support pensioner who finds employment will, in the majority of cases, have his or her pension suspended for up to two years-not finalised.

This piece of legislation has a lot to do with options; it has a lot to do with dignity. Up until now people have been bundled into one category, whether it be in the Job Search area or whether it be in determining eligibility for the invalid pension. Those of us who have dealt with applications for the invalid pension over the years have certainly seen the anomalies and injustices that can arise-a rigidity-in the application of a percentage of disability when deciding who is or is not to have support.

Many of the Bills that have gone before the House in recent years-certainly over the last two or three years-have been trying to overcome the rigidity of such legislation, trying to assess people on individual needs. In the past, particularly under the Disability Services Act (DSA) and under the Department of Community Services and Health, programs have been introduced and implemented to strive to overcome a phenomenon which can attack some people with disabilities and some people who are on invalid pensions-people lose confidence; they fear making the transition in breaking out into the healthy and so-called able world. Agoraphobia is a sickness, a disease experienced by many people who are cut off from the mainstream of life for whatever reason.

It is my belief that when we implement regulations and eligibility rules we have to look not only at the possibility that people might just want easy money when they stick to a pension-whether it be a disability pension, sickness pension or other benefit-but also at whether in fact they have lost confidence to the extent that they fear going beyond that weekly or monthly handout. I believe that in many cases this would be so.

When we are looking at legislation such as the Bills we are debating today, we must do so not only with sensitivity but also in the context of other legislation. The Bill is certainly about making the system efficient to the advantage of all, but it is also about change and the creation of new opportunities for people with disabilities, many of whom have been excluded from the mainstream of life's possibilities, risks and advantages for far too long. Protection has not really been to the advantage of a number of such people. I know there are different degrees of disability and it depends on the specific person.

The changes should be monitored carefully and certainly they will be reviewed. They should also be considered in the context of other Government programs aimed at assessing job needs and providing options. Since the introduction of the Disability Services Act, a range of services have developed whose primary goal is to obtain jobs in open employment for people with disabilities. I am very aware of the pace at which services such as Work Scope, Epic, Compass, Work Venture and Red Cross, to name just a few in Brisbane, have been developing, especially in the last three years, and I am impressed by how active they have been in locating jobs and providing on the job training and support for people with disabilities.

I have seen how changes under the Disability Services Act which may seem unremarkable to many people in the community, because they simply reflect things which are generally taken for granted, are in fact truly revolutionary. It is the very ordinariness, the very simplicity, of the basis underlying the changes which emphasises the revolutionary nature of the programs. It is that ordinariness which is the point.

All Australians are being given the opportunity to live the lifestyle option of their choice, including working in the place of their choice. It is important to note that one cannot bundle all people with disabilities under one category or assume that employment programs will open horizons for them all. Diverse individual potentials require a diversity of options, but the supported and open employment programs initiated under the Disability Services Act offer a large number of people with disabilities a diversity of new opportunities and experiences which once were just unimagined-the opportunity for real work in the regular work force with the same working conditions as everyone else, not a specially created, so-called disability job; the opportunity to earn a fair award based or productivity based wage and to enjoy both the benefits of a weekly pay packet, with its increased economic independence, and real leisure, not simply an enforced whiling away of the time; the opportunity to learn new skills; the opportunity to demonstrate enthusiasm and ability in the workplace; and, even more significantly, the opportunity to be free of the sheltered conformity of segregated factory style environments and to develop new relationships and make new friends with a wider range of people in the workplace and in the general community.

This is what is happening. Many new initiatives are continuing to be developed to remove the existing barriers and disincentives which prevent people with disabilities participating more fully in the working life of the community. Some of these barriers include lack of income security; employer-employee disincentives such as poor job design and job training; family attitudes; inaccessible transport, both public and private; unfair or inequitable wages; and a reluctant lack of self-confidence, which in itself turns people back again behind the doors and, in the past, has made them reliant on the pension. I am speaking of people who have the potential to go further.

New initiatives include the disability reform package announced in the 1990-91 Budget, which heralded the development of a more active income security system, concentrating on younger people and new entrants to the system. This strategy, which represents the most significant reform to the disability income security system since the early 1900s, allows for social security payments to be structured in such a way that people with severe disabilities will be able to develop their work force potential while maintaining an adequate and secure source of income support.

The disability task force, an interdepartmental committee composed of members of the Department of Community Services and Health, the Department of Industrial Relations, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training, has been established for the purpose of developing a framework for skills based wages which would operate within the mainstream industrial environment. The development of an appropriate and equitable system of wage payments is particularly important for people whose disability prevents them from earning a full award wage even with intensive support and training.

Since the introduction of the DSA, this Government has funded 225 new employment services, providing around 3,500 new program places. Our 1990-91 Budget package added a further 4,000 employment places by 1993-94. These additional places will be distributed between supported employment services and competitive employment services. At the same time, 5,000 extra places specifically targeted at people with disabilities will be provided in labour market programs administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The Government will also provide 4,500 additional rehabilitation places to cope with the demand for our more active income support strategy.

The challenge now is to ensure that these funds can create actual jobs tailored to the needs of people with disabilities. To facilitate the structural processes of change, the Government is also establishing a national technical assistance unit in Sydney for the purpose of providing independent expert technical assistance for the transition of sheltered workshops to eligible supported and competitive employment services under the DSA. A key element of the unit will be both the development and implementation of transition plans for sheltered workshops.

In closing, I think it is most important that, when we talk of taking away one particular allowance, or changing the name of one particular allowance, and altering segments of one particular system or program, there is no intent to leave-indeed no possibility of leaving-people without income support, without training, without assessment or without opportunities to reach their best potential, whether it be at home or out in the workplace with someone alongside them assisting them to enter that workplace.

There is a range of different options already opening up, and the Bills before the House are part of that overall package. They should be accepted as such with goodwill by both sides of the House, for it is truly said that when an efficient system is not available to cater for people with disabilities, the people who are sick, it is the carers, the providers and the community organisations who conduct the mop-up-and they are supporting the objectives of these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill and the Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill, I would first of all like to thank all honourable members for their contribution and in particular I thank the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), who I know has a very deep interest in these questions.
—What about the member for Dawson?
—I made a longer speech than her.

—I will come to the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) in a moment. I know for a fact that the honourable member for Lilley has a very deep interest in people with disabilities. The sincerity of her thoughts in that regard came out during her contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I also would like to thank the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) for her contribution and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) for his. As the honourable member for Dawson just stated: what about his speech? It was a 30-minute one, and that is fine. I know that the honourable member for Dawson also takes a very close interest in these matters affecting people with disabilities.

The Government has introduced a new culture in terms of the active employment strategy, for which Bills were passed not very long ago, and, in respect of people with disabilities, has also come up with a more active training culture so that we can try to make sure that those people who have some possibility of entering the work force are given every opportunity to do so.

For far too long there has been a situation in this country in which, for one reason or another, people as young as 18 years of age go on an invalid pension and, because of the lack of appropriate opportunities, stay on that invalid pension, sometimes for the whole of their lives. In other words, they get onto a treadmill; they get into a rut in which they think they are of no use to anybody and they are never given the opportunities to be able to better themselves.

The disability reform package complements the active employment strategy of the Government, and it is an encouragement to those who receive pensions or allowances to maximise their work potential so as to be prepared for any future work opportunities.

The Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill, as correctly stated by all honourable members, will introduce two streams of disability support pension-an inactive strategy and an active strategy. It has been stated by the honourable member for Dawson that there are not sufficient penalties in the Bill to make sure that people do the right thing and that those who can work do in fact take up the training opportunities availed to them. The Government is satisfied that the penalty provisions or the enforcement provisions are in order and that to make them any tougher would not do anybody any good.

The honourable member for Dawson suggested that the mobility allowance should be increased and that costs of disability should be recognised. Research on the varying costs of disablement is almost complete and proposals will soon be put to the Government. In the meantime the mobility allowance has been increased from $22 to $40 per fortnight.

The general criticisms that have been levelled at this Bill-and I speak now specifically of the disability reform package-do not take into account the fact that there was a lot of discussion and a lot of consultation with people and organisations involved in the disability field. They believe that this disability reform package is indeed a very good step and is something which should have happened a long time ago. All comment that we have received from welfare organisations so far has been good, and I am very pleased that the honourable member for Dawson did not come up with anybody who he believes has criticised these Bills from the welfare lobby, from councils of social service, et cetera, or from disability organisations, for that matter.

The honourable member for Dawson also put forward the proposition that this Bill is lax in the assessment of those who are disabled, with the result that they will go onto pensions. That is not so. The new arrangements will mean fewer will go onto a disability support pension because almost no notice will now be taken of socio-economic factors; the assessment will be almost entirely medical. Secondly, those on the new disability support pension or sickness allowance will be considered intensively for rehabilitation and vocational training. Refusal to participate in such programs may lead to non-payment or cancellation.

The other point to be made is that there will be a fair bit of cooperation here between the Department of Community Services and Health, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Social Security (DSS). The honourable member for Dawson expressed some reservations about the training of disability support officers and whether they would be sufficiently trained to be able to make these assessments as to who should go on the active strategy or the inactive strategy.

The answer to that is that there will be 75 disability support officers employed by the DSS. A consultant at this very point in time is being selected to do the training. The consultant will draw up a formal course with on the job experience as a component. Experienced DSS trainers will assist with this. The disability support officers will be trained over three months, between July and September, given that this starts on 1 October 1991.

The Disability Advisory Council will nominate other consultants to double-check the training to ensure that it is comprehensive. The Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Community Services and Health will be involved as is required and as is appropriate. I understand the cost will be of the order of $100,000. There will be similar ongoing training for new recruits.

Every opportunity will be given by the Government to ensure that everyone knows what it is that he or she can get out of this new program. Just to put it as simply as I can, the position will be that only those who apply for a disability support pension after 1 October will be affected by this. All those who are on invalid pensions now will retain their eligibility, except for approximately 2 per cent of those persons, who have already received a letter and are having their entitlement reviewed.

That does not mean that all those who are presently on an invalid pension cannot apply to go on the active stream. When an application is made it will go to a disability support officer, one of the 75 we will have trained by that time; that officer will make the assessment as to whether the person is 20 per cent disabled and as to whether he or she should go to the active stream or the inactive stream.

If the person involved goes to the inactive stream, he or she will automatically be awarded a disability support pension. If the disability support officer believes that that person should go on the active stream, he or she will then be referred to a panel made up of someone from the DSS, a Commonwealth rehabilitation officer and, of course, someone from the Department of Employment, Education and Training. At that stage the person will be entitled to have with him or her a friend or somebody who can put forward the situation in case the person involved cannot explain it. Appeal rights will be there if the person is not happy with the assessment.

It is very important to note also that the disability support officers will be looking at the medical records not only of a government medical officer but also of the doctor treating that person, so there will be notice taken of the individual's own doctor. That panel will then decide as to what sort of package it will put the person on and the sort of training it believes that person would benefit from.

It must be stated, and emphasised, that this legislation will provide many of these people with opportunities that they may have not had in the past. I accept, and understand, what the honourable member for Dawson would probably be thinking-that some people cannot, that some people with disabilities would be hopeless in the sense that they do not have the sorts of skills to go into any sort of job. I know what the honourable member feels with respect to sheltered workshops. I will not comment on that, but I have views, that in some instances, are not all that far away from his.

If we can give such people the opportunity, and they believe that they want to take that opportunity and give it a go, we should not stand in their way. In fact, we should give them all the help that we can. At the end of the day, this will give these people some dignity and the opportunity to enter into the mainstream of life and get the social interaction that occurs when one has a job. Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I and members here are very blessed that we do not have any disabilities. I can just imagine how lonely it could be if one were just stuck at home on an invalid pension.

The honourable member for Dawson also put forward the proposition that assessment of inability to work based on a prediction of being unable to work for two years could discourage people from attempting to work. That is not so. Any person granted a disability support pension who may have work potential will be assessed for rehabilitation, training or similar programs that could assist them to join the work force. People will not be left to their own devices when on a disability support pension, if work is a possibility. Training will be encouraged.

I turn now to some of the comments made by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford). We know that the honourable member can always be somewhat colourful and has views that sometimes are not exactly mainstream, shall I say; but, frankly, I think he insulted those people who come to this country as immigrants when he said that our immigration policy was so free or so easy, in his own words, that people would probably come here because they think they will get a handout. To me, that is an absolute insult. If he wants to attack the Government's immigration policy, that is up to him, but it is being a little over the top, if not bordering on racism--

TALK.START.PARA: —Knock it off!

—Well, if the honourable member is saying that people come here because they can get a handout, what he is saying is that people are prepared to come over here just to bludge on this country. I really do not think that there are people like that.
—What is racist about that?
—It is pretty racist because obviously he is referring to certain groups of people, certain ethnic populations, who might be on disability support pensions more than anyone else.
—They are your words.

—All right, maybe he is not being racist, but he is certainly being very tough on these people. If he wants to attack the Government's immigration program, he can do that at another time, not while we are discussing a Bill like this by which we are trying to help people with disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: While we are on the question of newcomers from other countries, I want to touch on the question of portability of pensions, which, I note, the honourable member for Dawson says that the Opposition supports. I refer to the portability of wives pensions and class B widows pensions. Last year, in its 1990 economic statement, the Government came forward with a number of propositions which would restrict the portability of these types of pensions. The Government has been concerned for some time now-in fact, since 1973 or 1974-that there were a small number of people in other countries, particularly Greece and Turkey, who were receiving wives pensions and class B widows pensions but had never been to Australia. So the Government restricted those pensions.

Later, after certain consultations between the Greek and Turkish communities and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), a number of exemptions were made to that law. It was amended further in May so that all de jure widows, whether or not they leave after July 1990, will be able to retain that pension.

I understand that the guillotine will bring this debate to a halt at 5.20 p.m., and I do not know whether my friend opposite wants to say anything further. I commend these Bills to the House. They are very good Bills and will really help many people. The Government and the Minister for Social Security should be congratulated on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill, I would like to first register my complaint about the fact that we are under guillotine yet again and dealing with over 30 Bills in one week. It seems that one of the many things that this Government cannot do is run this chamber, let alone run itself. This Bill, which the coalition will not be opposing, deals with a number of areas of local government, and four main ones in particular. The first two will give effect to the some of the decisions of last October's Special Premiers Conference. The first of them allows local road funding to be untied when it is given to local councils and the other relates to the maintenance of general purpose assistance in real terms to be in line with the levels in the States.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of other changes. One of those is to correct the funding formula for local government to take into account the decision to transfer the debits tax base to the States and Territories. If the Government had not made this amendment there would have been a reduction in general purpose grants to local government. In other words, yet again the Government was disorganised and has had to rush this Bill in without realising prior to this date that it overlooked this point.

The fourth change provides the Treasurer with discretion to set the level of general purpose assistance to local government similar to the general purpose assistance that has been given to the States. It clarifies the existing situation by allowing changes without it being necessary to have frequent changes to the legislation. Although this allows the States some further security in planning-in other words, some predictability for the next three years in general purpose assistance-the Government has allowed itself a safety clause. This obviously means that, if the economic conditions are not satisfactory or if there is a major deterioration, the Government has the opportunity, if it so wishes, to reduce the general purpose assistance. While, obviously, this clause has some merit, it also gives the Government a chance of a cop-out and therefore is of some concern to local government.

It is particularly of some concern when we see that local government could very easily be penalised, yet the Commonwealth itself has not shown the same sort of discipline that it has been willing to apply to itself to other levels of government. In other words, although it is cutting back-in the past, it has cut back quite a bit to the States-it has not made the same cuts in its own expenditure. If we do some analysis on this, we will find that spending by the Commonwealth under this Government has not fallen anything like that which has happened to the States and that which has been forced on local government from the assistance it gets from other levels of government.

While there may well be some arguments to say that the State budgets could be trimmed, the fact is that the Commonwealth has many areas where it could cut. To demonstrate our bona fides on this, before the 1990 election the coalition parties showed details under our Economic Action Plan of how we could cut $3 billion off Commonwealth expenditure. We demonstrated it in considerable detail. When we talk about cuts to government expenditure we can show exactly how it can be done.

The Commonwealth Government is still not only trying to escape the cuts that it wants to apply to other levels of government but is also, by putting in this escape clause, intending to try to make the States and local government carry the burden of the sort of discipline that it should be applying to itself.

I now turn to the question of road funding, which is an integral part of this legislation. While we have no objection to local government getting more flexibility in how it spends the money that it is getting, there is some concern about what this will mean in the longer term. There is no doubt that the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is also concerned because it will reduce those photo opportunities that he seems to love to have when he is travelling around Australia. Maybe the Minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government (Ms Fatin), might like to take up the challenge and try to match his efforts. It seems that he spends most of his time standing in front of a camera or a microphone trying to get publicity.

However, we are pleased to see that road funding at this stage will continue to be identified. We would like to see some more tangible evidence that motorists will know that the money that has been raised from their taxes, particularly fuel tax, will be maintained in real terms in the expected funding. I will come back to the question of the level of funding for roads in a minute.

Obviously, local government is concerned about the question of full absorption because, once we take away any connection with road funding in any form, local government could very easily be squeezed in times of an economic downturn, such as the recession that we have had forced on us by the present Government. That squeeze could affect particularly local roads.

The record of the present Government when it comes to road funding is appalling. In the last seven years, in real terms we have seen the amount of money allocated to roads drop by 27 per cent, yet at the same time the amount of revenue that has gone to the Commonwealth from fuel excise has increased by over 90 per cent. Before the last election, the coalition gave a very clear undertaking that, if we were elected, we would increase over three years the amount of funds going out of existing fuel taxes to roads by $1,000m.

It is clear that the Commonwealth's cutting back on road funding over the last seven years has had a very marked effect on our road network. We have seen a rapid deterioration in many parts of our road network. Often, we have seen local councils rip up local roads and turn them back to gravel. We have seen sealed roads with potholes in them like we have not seen around this country for decades and we have seen gravel roads which were once bitumen roads. They are a sign of what has happened because the Government has cut back on road funding.

If one looks at this situation, one finds it is far more serious than that. If one does an analysis of our major roads, one finds that over half have surfaces over 20 years old. Many are approaching the end of the normal lifespan of a road and some have even gone past it. It is clear that a major infrastructure problem is building up because the Government, in its short sighted economics, has not looked forward to what it means to take these cuts, which may save money in the short term but which will prove extremely expensive in the long term. Had many of these roads been properly maintained and upgraded when necessary, we might not be facing the massive bill over the next decade.

We must remember that for many people roads are the only way they can travel; roads are a vital part of our communication network. That is why I think the Government stands condemned for allowing so much of this vital network-one of the country's most valuable assets-to deteriorate in a way that has not been seen since the war. This is against the background of the challenge that will be faced by the roads in the level of usage expected over the next decade. As the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is so fond of saying, the freight task is expected to double over the next decade. It is a wonder the Minister does not say with his next breath that we will have to match that with an increase in road funding. Yet, as I have said, over the last seven years road funding from the Commonwealth has dropped in real terms by 27 per cent, and the number of cars on the road is expected to increase by about 30 per cent over the next decade. Why has the money going to roads not been increased to match this and to anticipate what the need will be?

Not only that; it is estimated that up to 30 per cent of car crashes are due in part to bad roads. The estimated cost of a fatality which occurs on the roads is about $475,000; that figure could be revised shortly. This is a massive cost, not only in human suffering for those directly connected with the person who unfortunately loses his life, but also to the nation.

The majority of people in road accidents do not die, and the cost of caring for someone with severe disabilities caused by a road accident could be in excess of $800,000. The cost of bad roads is enormous in terms of human suffering and the economy. There is ample evidence around to show that better roads are safer roads. In many places the cost of improving those roads can be undertaken without massive changes. For example, an extra metre on road width can reduce head-on and run off road crashes by 20 per cent; improving or increasing the number of passing lanes on many roads can cut crashes by as much as 50 per cent; and replacing an undivided road with a freeway, where that can be afforded, can cut down the number of crashes by 90 per cent.

This is a great opportunity for the Government to demonstrate its bona fides. When we talk about roads and funding for local roads, we should recognise the value of those roads. If we look at what it means to the community to have those roads upgraded to the level we could reasonably afford if we gave them priority, I think in terms of lives and the economics the savings would be extensive.

As I pointed out, the Government's record on road funding is not good. One suspects that may reflect a number of other things in the Government's record, and its problems, over the past few days. While this Bill gives local government a three-year undertaking, one must ask whether that will be honoured. That is one of the major points the Government will have to stand by. One problem with that is that the Government might not be here for three years. I can assure all those concerned about that matter that the coalition parties demonstrated their bona fides in their concern for roads and, particularly, for local government before the last election; that is, the coalition will give local government the support it so justly deserves.

While the coalition does not oppose this Bill, it believes there is a real risk that, by taking road funding for local roads out of the Australian Land Transport Development Trust Fund and sourcing it from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, the Government has greater scope and opportunity to reduce the amount of money going to roads in future years. Given the Government's record already in reducing funds to roads when we have a trust fund for the land transport portfolio, local government has every right to feel nervous about what this Bill will mean in the long term.

It is a significant fact that, in many councils which have received major grants throughout Australia, there is a correlation almost between the number of Taj Mahals and the luxury of the administrative offices. I think there is a prima facie case against any system of grants to local government.

Nevertheless, there are so many difficulties and so many variations in the whole local government structure, given its historical basis, that it is obviously impossible in the foreseeable future to take a purist line and to advocate a local government totally self-funding at an independent level. But I think that should be the long term goal for local government and over the next few years, when we see a very close examination of the restructuring of Commonwealth-State relations, this should be the goal for local government.

One of the problems is that no-one has really ever defined what local government is supposed to do. We all know that over the past couple of decades its services have grown like topsy. That has come about through a mixture of community pressures, empire building and State-Federal initiatives-there has really been no direction to it-but we do know that local government has expanded dramatically, and we cannot really establish any sensible method of funding until we know where it is all going.

I believe that the principle of delivering public services at the lowest possible level is certainly a good principle, and we have got to pursue it, but we have enormous problems at local government with overservicing and wide variations in standards of different councils. One of the worst defects, of course, is the bureaucracy of local government: their salaries are tied basically to expenditure. Until we can address those sorts of problems, the thought of massive untied grants is pretty frightening.

On the basis that local government does need funds over and above its capacity to raise local funds, the next question is: should funding come from the States or should it come from the Commonwealth? The more one looks at it, the more there is a very good case for the Commonwealth to get out of direct funding and include all local government funding in States' grants.

I am not preaching States' rights; I think that is a separate question. States will exist for the foreseeable future, whether they are good or bad, but no amount of fiddling with the funding of local government will really have any bearing on the question of States' rights. After all, the only public test of this question of where funding should come from was the 1974 referendum to give the Commonwealth constitutional power to make grants direct to local government-and of course that was comprehensively defeated.

As things stand, the funding to local government is incredibly complex and opaque and is a confusion of the State and Commonwealth, compounded with the complexity of fiscal equalisation and a whole range of other various needs based formulas. Certainly, to me, it was a merciful relief that even the Commonwealth Grants Commission had to give up, to some extent, the push for fiscal equalisation this year when it looked at the bizarre results that it produced. I think the whole question of fiscal equalisation is a subject on which we have to spend a lot more time over the next few years. At the moment it is very much an academically based exercise which, if pursued, can only produce quite ridiculous results. At present, a substantial saving in administrative expenses, which would certainly be a bonus in clarity at both State and Federal levels, would be achieved if all local government grants from the Commonwealth were included in general purpose grants for the States.

I have certainly got nothing personal against the Minister for Local Government (Ms Fatin), who I think has done a very good job, but I really think we could abolish the office of Minister for Local Government and the associated bureaucracy. I think there would be many more public advantages to such a step than there would be disadvantages.

So I support the Bill to the extent that it is a very small move towards getting the Commonwealth out of direct funding of local government, but I think the suggestions in the second reading speech of the Minister that the Bill will strengthen the capacity of local government and raise the status of local government are fairly exaggerated. The retention of the arrangement under the Australian Land Transport Development Act of maintaining what could only be called a slush fund of $24m has very little merit, other than facilitating a little pork-barrelling at election time.

Finally, as the honourable member for Wannon is still in the chamber, I was a little disappointed to see the Opposition spokesman trot out some of the platitudes of the motoring organisations and the road transport lobby for more road funding and to use the Bill for that purpose. The problem of roads in Australia can never be solved until we get some basis for relating cost to usage. While we do not have that nexus, we will always have unlimited demand which cannot be funded without dramatically reducing many other services. We have to move as fast as we can over the next few years towards full cost recovery. At the moment, any sensible person knows that the road transport industry is riding on the back of the private motorist and that the private motorist, far from being soaked, as is the usual line of the motoring organisations, is being heavily subsidised.

An examination of all the material we now have shows that fuel costs should be over $2 a litre if full road cost recovery was really wanted. A result of all these distortions is that we have a community with unreal expectations, a complete distortion of land use-both rural and urban-throughout the country, a complete distortion of our transport systems, and a misallocation of funds between national State highways and local roads. Our only hope is to move steadily towards full cost recovery to get things on a proper basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have last minute legislation for the wool industry, a repeat of last year, with major legislation for this great Australian industry coming in in the dying hours of Parliament when the proposals have to be in place by 1 July. The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill, the Australian Wool Corporation Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill, the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills were introduced at 1 a.m. last Friday morning. There has been no time for anybody, including those in the industry, to study fully all the detail and the implications. We now have a guillotine for three hours for the main debate, and we have achieved that extra time for the guillotine only by agreeing to reduce the time to debate the Fisheries Administration Bill and related Bills tomorrow morning.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a most unsatisfactory situation for this most important rural industry in Australia, the wool industry. It comes at a time of great difficulty for people engaged in the industry. All farmers are facing the worst situation since the Depression of the 1930s, and for woolgrowers the worst is still to come. The real impact of lower incomes will occur over the next 12 months and if the drought continues over much of Australia it will be even worse.

Just to give some indication of projections concerning woolgrowers' income, I want to cite some figures from the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly of March. Those figures are already out of date. When one looks at farm cash operating surplus for the sheep industry, in 1989-90 there was a cash operating surplus of $50,407 per sheep farmer; in 1990-91-that is, this year just ending-it was down to $5,724, a reduction of 89 per cent; and for next year, 1991-92, the projection is that it will be a negative figure of minus $626, a further fall by 111 per cent. That is a frightening figure.

Table 5.1 of the report of the Vines Committee of Inquiry into the Wool Industry and the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council concerning wool farmers' income shows distribution of farm cash operating surplus for specialist sheep producers in 1991-92; the figure here is based on 400c kilogram clean net of tax, which means a figure of about 460c gross average price for wool. At that level 25 per cent of all specialist sheep farmers will earn a negative figure of at least minus $13,920, and 50 per cent of farmers will have a figure of minus $620.

That gives the impact of what is still to come for the woolgrowers of Australia. If this drought continues, there will obviously be a great cost to woolgrowers. Many will face the terrible dilemma as to whether it will pay to feed sheep, and there will be reduced production as well.

This very grave financial situation confronting our woolgrowers emphasises the crucial part of all of the Bills before us tonight, that is, the tax level or the levy and the impact that a higher than necessary levy rate can have on thousands of woolgrowers. It can force them off the land by fire sales of their properties. After that, there will be fewer growers to pay out the stockpile debt for the remaining years, with even more pressure on those still remaining.

Throughout the wool debate and the wool crisis of the last 12 months or so, I believe the coalition has maintained a consistent and positive policy. At all times we have emphasised the importance of having a supply-demand balance to get the price up. That was initially in relation to a flock reduction scheme, which was the only positive proposal by anybody in the industry to save the floor price. That proposal was put up about nine months ago-to bring supply back so that the pressure would come off that mounting stockpile. We supported the floor price until such time as the Government terminated that scheme. We have more recently used the proposal for a flock reduction scheme as a method to be able to reduce the levy applying to growers in the marketing situation since the termination of the floor price.

At all times we have opposed quotas, because they do not work. We initiated a proposal for wool credit sales to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and both the National Party and Liberal Party had delegations of parliamentarians to China for the purpose, among other things, of discussing and encouraging the purchase of Australian wool by that country. Once the floor price was terminated, we recognised that it was more beneficial for putting security or stability back in the industry not to talk about attempting to reinstate such a scheme.

Initially and at various stages of the debate, many people in the wool industry did not accept or agree with what we were proposing. Some did. I believe the great majority of woolgrowers in Australia now accept that what we were proposing at various stages was a sensible and positive response to the problems and that they were the correct responses by ourselves as the coalition parties.

This brings me to the Vines Committee recommendations, which were presented at the end of March. I believe the Vines Committee made a series of comprehensive and valuable recommendations. Basically that report set the parameters for the debate that has taken place since. Those recommendations are valuable, even if not all of them have been accepted either by the coalition parties or, for that matter, the Government. For example, with the question of the management of the stockpile, Vines emphasised that we need to have predictability and accountability. But people have differed in their views as to the best way to achieve that management.

The two parameters of the Vines Committee have held up very well. The first is that 12 per cent is the maximum levy or tax which woolgrowers can afford. The Vines Committee documented that, as have plenty of other people. Secondly, that 900 million kilograms is a safe and reasonable basis of sales of Australian wool each year. With a lower price that figure may be able to be increased, but I believe it is too soon for us to say whether that is the case or not. I believe that 900 million kilograms is still there as a benchmark.

The market has moved since the Vines Committee recommendations went to press, but those particular points are still very valid. When the Vines recommendations were released we did not wait for the Government to announce its decision. We accepted the challenge to produce a levy figure which was lower than 12 per cent, and which was sustainable and credible. Obviously any figure lower than 12 per cent must be to the value of the viability of thousands of Australian woolgrowers. We were able to do so because, once again, we factored in the flock reduction scheme so that wool would be removed from the market. Reducing supply below that 900 million kilogram figure would allow wool to be sold from the stockpile and then be utilised to either reduce the principal debt or reduce the debt servicing cost.

There was also a need to have a sensible level of asset sales of the non-wool assets of the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC). Through that debate, and since, the general accuracy of the figures we produced has been challenged, but it has not been proven to be wrong.

Initially individual members of the Australian Wool Council were critical of our putting forward this positive proposal because they were hoping that the Government would accept the Vines recommendation of no more than 12 per cent. Of course, the Government did not. The Government went for 15 per cent. So the Wool Council now accepts the sense of a flock reduction scheme, at least as an option.

Honourable members should remember that there was a successful flock reduction scheme which removed 11 million sheep. If it had been continued until the present, there is no doubt that the future of woolgrowers would have been far more assured for next year than is now the case. The Wool Council also accepts the priority of asset sales in relation to keeping that levy down. This evening a statement from the Wool Council has been released supporting our proposal which we released earlier today.

Since the Vines Committee and the release of our figures, the market has continued to improve. The supplementary payments and the necessary borrowings are well down; interest rates are falling; and supply is 130,000 bales short of what was predicted for this year.

Just last week the projections for production next year were reduced to 881 million kilograms and it is generally believed that they will fall to at least 850 million kilograms with the next projection period, partly because of the flock reduction, the drought and because it is just not economic to keep certain types of sheep.

In that time the price has increased from 435c a kilogram to 450c a kilogram, and now to 580c a kilogram. The projections we have-I think most people are using these projections now-are around the 450c a kilogram figure. The projections for the average price for next year will certainly be in excess of 450c and, when they are announced, could be around 475c.

It is my understanding that the Wool Corporation initially recommended that a 12 to 13 per cent levy would be adequate. That was before these better figures became available. The Government, through the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), stuck to 15 per cent. Presumably it was the best he could get through the Cabinet because the alternative assumption of sticking to 15 per cent would mean that he wanted to inflict unnecessary pain on thousands of Australian woolgrowers. No alternative assumption could be made. No matter how it is rationalised now, that is the realistic situation.

I sought, and received, the approval of the previous Minister at the table to incorporate some figures in Hansard indicating the justification for the amendment which I will be moving towards the conclusion of my speech to the effect that a 10 per cent maximum is all that is necessary. I will be moving amendments to that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The significant point for woolgrowers is around asset sales. That is the whole crux of 10 per cent versus 15 per cent. It is a question of what level of asset sales are reasonable from the Wool Corporation and where receipts from those asset sales should be applied.

It would not surprise me at all if the Government, in attempting to support its unsustainable and unnecessarily cruel figure of 15 per cent, claims that it can sell only $40m of the $280m to $300m of the assets of the Wool Corporation in the next financial year. We have had repeated indications that $120m is quite a reasonable figure in the first year and in the second year. If the Government wants to maintain that sort of situation, on the basis on which it is operating it should be honest and say how many years it will take for the whole debt to be removed. Will it be four years or five years? It will certainly be far shorter than the seven years which the Government originally proposed.

The Government is, once again, showing its lack of sympathy and lack of understanding for the problems facing woolgrowers. What does it matter if it takes one year or two years more to pay the whole debt off if it maintains the viability of Australia's woolgrowers. If we do have a maximum of 10 per cent, I believe that will also put sensible pressure on the Wool Corporation and the Wool Realisation Commission to perform.

The former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, in his second reading speech tried to indicate that there was no significant difference with figures below a 15 per cent tax level. I assure the House that that is not the case. For example, the difference between a 10 per cent levy and a 15 per cent levy for a woolgrower, say, with 5,000 sheep at 450c a kilogram clean is close to $3,500; for 10,000 sheep it is obviously double that, about $7,000. The Minister is not speaking about hundreds but thousands of dollars. If that does not sound a big amount of money, remember that the average woolgrower this coming year will have a negative income. Several thousands of dollars becomes a very significant figure in that situation.

If we compare the choice of Wool Corporation asset sales to farmers asset sales-that is, the selling up of individual woolgrowers-we find that anyone with any sympathy or understanding for rural Australia, for the future of the wool industry or for the ultimate cost to the taxpayer, because of what it could mean in welfare payments, must come down on the side of asset sales from the Wool Corporation rather than asset sales of farmers' individual properties. That is what the choice is in stark form.

It has been said that we should not go ahead with any significant amount of non-wool assets of the AWC because it is not the best time to have sales in Melbourne. I have been told that close to 70 per cent of those non-wool assets-those stores and warehouses of the Wool Corporation-are not holding any wool at all. They are certainly serving a reasonable commercial purpose and some are returning quite a good price of 13 per cent to 14 per cent. If they are, that would be a good time to sell them, because that is a reasonable return for the buyer. But if they are not, the loss to the wool industry from selling $120m worth of assets at the present time, as against what could be obtained on a maximum market, is minor compared with the far greater capital loss for thousands of Australian farmers who would be sold up because of that significant difference between a 10 per cent and 15 per cent levy.

Anyone's calculations, whether they are ours or those of the Government-and I would be very interested to see the Government's projections when it produces them-are really about guesstimates of the price and production over the next few years and about the number of years it is thought essential for the whole thing to be wound up. I make this plea to the Government: for the sake of the woolgrowers of Australia, the future of the industry, look again at the 15 per cent and look again at how many years that will be paid out, and make a decision for the sake of those growers.
With that in mind, I move a second reading amendment as follows:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-
(a) regrets the Government's unnecessary decision to create a Wool Realisation Commission separate from the Australian Wool Corporation;

(b) regrets the Government's failure to provide some certainty in the wool market by not implementing an orderly schedule, with appropriate legislative authority, for releasing specified quantities of wool from the Australian Wool Corporation's stockpile; and
(c) calls on the Government to support a properly managed industry funded flock reduction scheme to be introduced if and when the industry agrees such a scheme is necessary.

At a later stage-if time permits with the operation of the guillotine-in the debate in committee on the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills I will be moving for a reduction from 15 per cent to 10 per cent, and at the second reading stage on the Australian Wool Corporation Bill I will be moving another second reading amendment.

The amendment that I have just moved reaffirms our policy of a predictable and accountable release from the stockpile on a predetermined volume basis, which we believe is the best method. We believe that it was unnecessary to create another body, by separating the AWC from the wool realisation aspects, if you like, of determining the stockpile-with no need for a separate Wool Realisation Commission-reaffirming the sense of at least having a flock reduction scheme in the legislation as an option for woolgrowers in the future, at their own cost.

There are many other aspects to this Bill, and more amendments will be moved in the Senate as we pursue this very important piece of legislation. If I have time, I will be indicating in another second reading debate, on the Australian Wool Corporation Bill, the importance of having an Industry Commission inquiry into the level and method of wool promotion to ensure that Australian woolgrowers are receiving maximum benefit for the very large amounts of money, particularly at this difficult time, that they are putting into wool promotion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given a fair go.

—Yes, being given a fair go. Also, one has to question whether or not in some years time the Wool Corporation, as being reconstituted now, would still be the most appropriate body or way for the wool industry to organise certain functions. There is the question as to whether or not carpet wool should be included in the debt repayment levy arrangements. There is the question of the industry council, of the conduct of the general meeting, and who will receive the final profit. I have no doubt that there will be a final profit from the settlement of the stockpile, and it has to be made far clearer that it will be the growers of Australia and not Consolidated Revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: To conclude, once again I ask the Government to check the figures, as everybody else in the industry has, and to acknowledge that a far lower figure is credible, sustainable and sensible at this time for the future of this great industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The five cognate Bills under discussion this evening are the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991, the Australian Wool Corporation Bill 1991, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill 1991, the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill 1991, and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1991. At the outset I pay tribute and give credit to the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, now the Treasurer, Mr John Kerin, for the work and dedication that he has put into the portfolio and these Bills over our four terms of government. There is no doubt that John Kerin has held the respect of honourable members on both sides of this House and certainly people in the bush during times that have been very tough and will be very tough for the next couple of years.

SPEECH.PARA: I also welcome the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Simon Crean, who will do an outstanding job. The way in which the new Minister was able to bring about commonsense in the industrial relations field, to work through healing processes and to see a reduction of 10 per cent in non-farm unit labour costs demonstrates that, with his capacity for working for the country and for the bush, he will fulfil adequately the role that John Kerin has left.

The aim of this package of Bills is to establish a new institutional structure and marketing arrangements in the wool industry in the absence of the reserve price scheme. Three new bodies-the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, the new Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool Research and Development Corporation-will replace the present Australian Wool Corporation.

The Australian Wool Realisation Commission has a life expectancy of a maximum of approximately seven years. It will play a pivotal role in the resolution of the present problems facing the wool industry. It has the role of disposing of the stockpiles and non-wool assets, and repayment of the wool debt. The establishment of the new Australian Wool Corporation to promote the wool industry will facilitate the marketing of wool and will develop and implement programs to safeguard the quality of Australian wool. There is no doubt that Australian wool is the best quality in the world and, with that going for us, we will get back on track.

The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill 1991 makes a number of changes to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1990 that provide for the establishment by regulation of the new Australian Wool Research and Development Corporation. It will be responsible for the strategic planning and funding of research and development projects.

The Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill 1991 provides for primary industries councils to be established by regulation. The Australian Wool Industry Council will be responsible for the coordination of the overall strategic directions for the wool industry.

In a study commissioned by the Wool Council of Australia in May this year, it was concluded that the Government's analysis, based on information then available, does imply a 15 per cent wool tax. It was stated that the 15 per cent wool tax remains necessary for 1991-92 if the Government's minimum debt repayment is to be met.

The comprehensive plan for recovery of the wool industry allows it to retain responsibility for its own destiny while receiving the continued support of the Australian Government. These measures responsibly address the biggest challenge our wool industry has faced in modern times.

The wool industry is facing a major adjustment to market prices and, at the same time, is saddled with an enormous debt and a huge stockpile of wool. We need to build a strong future for wool. The seven-year debt repayment will mean that there will be no fire sale from the stockpile. Seven years is a maximum and it may well be that the market circumstances will enable the debt to be paid off earlier. Current price levels make wool very competitive against other fibres. This will enable Australian wools to regain the market share that we have lost to our competitors.

We all know of the immense pressure that woolgrowers are facing. The rate of the wool tax has been a major concern to growers. There has been an enormous range of views but a balance has had to be found between the national interest objectives of debt management and the health of the industry on the one hand and the management of the debt and stockpile and consequent financial burden on growers on the other. The decision on wool tax reflects the Government's decision that responsibility for the debt will remain with the industry.

In determining the most appropriate tax rate for the industry, the Government had to weigh two competing objectives-first, the need to ensure the continued viability of the Australian wool industry and, secondly, the need to protect the Commonwealth's-and by that, I mean the taxpayers'-contingent liability for the Australian Wool Corporation debt. In recognition of the position that woolgrowers face in the first year, the Government is underwriting asset sales with a $200m interest free loan and has required the debt to be reduced by some $20m in 1991-92.

I feel it is important for all parties involved in our great Australian wool industry-that is, government, growers and the industry itself-to continue to work together. If we do that, we will come through these tough times. I believe that there is a better understanding, not only in the bush but on both sides of this House, that we need to have co-operation and common sense if we are to overcome these difficulties. This is the case not just in wool but, of course, in the grains industry and now, sadly, in the sugar industry. Since this time last year, sugar prices have dropped by some 50 per cent as well.

Several other propositions have been put forward in regard to solving the problem. The honourable member for Murray mentioned one-a quota scheme-which both he and I oppose. Such a scheme would not work and it would impact unfairly on the finer wool producers who do not have the same sorts of difficulties. I have never believed that quota schemes work in such circumstances.

One of the difficulties is flock reduction. This is an understandably hard area because reducing stock involves putting down or destroying animals. The situation is quite different in the case of the sugar industry because making reductions means ploughing out 50 acres of cane. Nevertheless, the effect, in the circumstances, is just the same.

I oppose the amendment. But because of the short time that has been allowed for this debate and the number of speakers on this legislation-I note that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who has a very strong interest in the wool industry, who represents almost all of Western Australia, and whose electorate is larger than most European countries and has a massive number of sheep, is to speak-I will conclude my remarks to allow the honourable member and members on the other side of the House to contribute to these very important Bills which are being discussed at a very serious and important time in the history of the wool industry.
