The Corporation anticipates that next year it will be able to borrow its funds at just under 11 per cent. The figures that the honourable member for Murray has asked to be incorporated have been arrived at on that basis.

On the other hand, growers whose debt in agriculture has risen from about $7 billion in 1985 to nigh on $12 billion today, will be paying 14, 15, 16 or, with penalties, up to 19 and 20 per cent, depending on their circumstances. It seems to me that, if we have the opportunity to do so, the growers should take advantage of the price at which the Corporation can borrow funds, the interest rate that it can borrow at, because, after all, the Corporation has a government guarantee. It is reasonable and, in fact, absolutely necessary, to try our hardest to mitigate the burden on those growers.

The honourable member for Hinkler said that the Government's minimum repayment schedule has to be met and that 15 per cent will be needed. We disagree. Seven years are not needed if we are to levy people 15 per cent; I suggest that we would not even need a levy of 15 per cent if we were to try to get rid of this debt over five years.

Just before going into those details, I would like to make a point or two about the ability of the Australian Wool Corporation to borrow, if you like, on behalf of the industry. I would like to say something about the effect of that statutory corporation borrowing $2.88 billion at the peak on behalf of woolgrowers.

The AWC, having accumulated in the market support fund about $1.7 billion of growers' funds, found that it could not buy wool without going into debt. So off it went to the banks and borrowed, as I said, $2.8 billion. That, of course, was the cream on the top of growers' wool cheques. It was an amount of money that they were to get that was borrowed on their behalf over and above the bid price on the day. So we could say that that was the top part of their income-it was the cream, if you like, of growers' wool cheques.

I think it is reasonable to assume that a large amount of tax-that is personal income tax or corporate tax in the case of farming corporations-was paid on the $2.8 billion that was borrowed on behalf of these growers. Some people say that it is as high as $1 billion-but let us be conservative and say that it was $800m. So, $2 billion of the $2.8 billion that was borrowed on their behalf, fell into the hands of the growers and $800m or so went off to the tax collector and resides in the hands of the Government.

That does not take into account the fact that in 1984 the Government got rid of the income equalisation deposits (IED) scheme, a scheme which most people now believe should be brought back and which, in these very high peak years, would have allowed growers to put aside a little bit of hay for the hard times. In fact, that is what it was designed for. Perhaps there could have been even further moneys residing, albeit temporarily, in the hands of the Government if that IED scheme had been brought back before 30 June last year instead of on 1 July, which, I have to say, seemed to us to be done to avoid the Government having to lose taxation revenue in the 1989-90 year.

If at the end of the wind-up of this whole stockpile, when we have finally sold it all off, it turns out that there is a deficit to the guarantor-that is, the Government-it seems to me that the Government will have a little bit of wherewithal with which to pay it. After all, the Government is saying that the growers should meet the whole of the debt-the whole $2.8 billion, $2.5 billion, $2.6 billion, or whatever it will be on 30 June. It looks as though it will be about $2.6 billion. Are we saying that the Government can keep the moneys that it has received out of the tax, with the exception of the $300m and perhaps the $44m that it will put in on interest on the $200m that it is kicking into the till, and that the growers should pay all the rest? I am not sure that that is exactly a reasonable proposition. That is something that the Government will have to take into account, and should take into account.

History shows that we on this side of the House have taken a bipartisan view in the debate on these wool problems, as much as is possible, since it was obvious that the industry was in big trouble and, as I said earlier, since we managed to dissipate the $1.7 billion of growers' funds that were in the market support fund. As I have said before in this House, in 1987 the Government designed the legislation which allowed the reserve price to be put so high that we dissipated that $1.7 billion and then got rid of another $2.8 billion.

The Government had a member on the board of the Corporation who, my information says, was probably in favour of 900c. Even if that were not true, he certainly voted for 870c. The responsibility therefore-as many people have said and we have said many times-is a dual responsibility which comes down both on the growers and on the Government.

For nigh on nine months now we have been saying that there is a way to help mitigate this obligation-that is, by the introduction of a flock reduction scheme. I will not spend too much time on it but finally, one way or another, we did coerce the Corporation into introducing it. It set out to remove an extra 20 million sheep, over and above the normal kill, in 12 months. It successfully got rid of 11 million in 2 1/2 months and then, sadly, the scheme came to a halt. I cannot understand why that was the case.

The former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, now the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), said in this House that he was very happy to spend $100m on that scheme. In fact, he told some of us privately that, if that was spent, he was happy to go on. The scheme was apparently a great success. It managed to take out some of next year's wool supply-probably 40 to 50 million kilograms of it-at a price of 80c a kilogram, which, had it gone on, would have enabled us to sell even more wool out of the stockpile next year. We will be able to sell some, no doubt, but there were those who did not have the stomach for the scheme, those who could not do the sums, or those who simply did not know enough about the wool industry to understand that, if those sheep had come out fast, then the price would have improved earlier and some value would have been put into people's sale sheep, into their 1 1/2 and 5 1/2-year-old sheep. Unfortunately, for all the wrong reasons, that scheme came to a halt and we are in a position today, as has been proven by the Wool Corporation's consultants, in which we will be forced to pay a higher levy than would otherwise have been the case.

So far we have no figures from the Government to show how it reached a figure of 15 per cent. I understand that the Government had in mind the figure of 15 per cent a few weeks ago and then it was reduced to 12 per cent, as announced in a press release that the former Minister put out at the time-or was it in a letter that he wrote to all the woolgrowers? Since then we have had no figures at all to show how the Government reached that decision. If it is going to come up with that sort of figure, then it really ought to be throwing some figures around to justify it.

The honourable member for Murray has put some figures on the table. He has shown that we can get nearly a 4 per cent decrease in the levy in the first year. After all, these next two years will be the years that make or break the woolgrowers. He has shown that, by varying the amount of assets sales, for every $20m-odd of assets sales we can reduce the levy by one per cent in the first year, and we can do it again in the second year. In fact, it is quite a reasonable assumption that we will sell $120m worth of assets not only in the first year but also in the second year.

By that time, the stockpile will be starting to reduce. We already know that the annual production of sheep is starting to reduce. In two years' time we will be well down in the number of kilograms coming up for sale. I would suggest that we will have a lessening of the amount of wool left in the stockpile, we will have a low annual production, and people will start to wonder where the wool is coming from, so the price will start to rise. Every one of these sums ought to be based on the fact that the price will rise, because it most surely will. It already came up to nearly 600c because of a temporary shortage at the end of this selling season. Everybody knows that there will be plenty of wool on the market at the beginning of the next selling season when it opens in July-August. We can reduce the burden on growers quite radically by changing the amount of assets sales in the first year.

In our proposal we have done nothing to reduce the promotion and research and development more than would seem sensible in these circumstances. We have come up with levy figures that vary from 9.1 per cent down to 8 per cent. As I said earlier, for some extraordinary reason neither the wool industry leaders nor the Government had the stomach to go on with the flock reduction scheme, although the growers themselves, of course, grabbed it with alacrity. Not only did they grab it with alacrity, but some of those same leaders sold their own sheep into this scheme for the measly amount of $1.80, and on other occasions for as low at $5, for young sheep. We could have had a lesser levy if anybody had had the foresight to take it up. I suggest to the Minister that 15 per cent is an impossibility.

I declare an interest in this matter because I am a woolgrower. Having done the sums backwards, forwards and sideways, I can tell the Minister that, if 15 per cent is going to be around for the next four or five years, an enormous number of people will go out of this industry. That is not what we want. I do not agree with those who say that we have to lose a lot of people out of this industry. We are used to low prices on and off for agricultural commodities. We are not used to paying 20 per cent interest rates for 5 1/2 years. For that we can thank the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who has left his post in recent days. We are not used to paying 20 per cent interest rates. This industry, like almost every other small business industry in this country, has been caught on that high interest rate wave. When that wave breaks a lot of people will go out altogether.

I would like to comment on one other thing before I finish-that is, I thought that efficiency was the name of the game. But now we have the International Wool Secretariat with its board; we have the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, with a board of nine members; we have the AWC, with a board of a similar number; we have the Australian Wool Research and Development Corporation, with another board of about the same size; and we have the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council.

If we are really efficient, surely we do not need five institutions running under the auspices of the Government. Admittedly, one or two of those institutions-at least one-will disappear as the stockpile is sold, but this seems to the Opposition to be an awful lot of institutions, an awful lot of directors, an awful lot of expense and an awful great temptation to build policies to make sure that those people stay in jobs. It is a great temptation for them.

I come back to the major point: we have run these figures time and time again over the past few months; we have put them in the public arena and nobody has been able to shoot holes in them. There is absolutely no chance that growers can continue to pay a levy of 15 per cent, or indeed anything over 10 per cent, and the Government ought to take up its part of the obligations-having stood as guarantor and having been responsible for the legislation which brought about this enormous debt, along with the woolgrowers-stand in its place and give the growers still in the industry today a chance to be there in five years time when the Wool Realisation Commission has done its job. If that is the case, my guess is that there will be a repayment of some moneys to growers still in the business or to those who contributed to the previous $1.7 billion, because the price of wool will go up as the stockpile reduces.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating these cognate Bills tonight, I intend to address only two of them: the Australian Wool Corporation Bill and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill; I might briefly touch on the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do so, I would like to say that I am absolutely appalled at the response from the agro-political industry in this country to the appointment of the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) as the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Firstly, that industry has a proven track record of incompetence; its performance during the whole wool fiasco was appalling. It saddens me that the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia, whose performance is relatively good compared with that of the others, also jumped on this bandwagon. I believe the new Minister will bring to the wool industry a new vision; he comes free of and uncluttered by the old prejudices; he brings a keen intellect; and I believe he will bring the guts and determination this industry so sadly needs and has not had in the past.
These Bills concern me. In the words of the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in his second reading speech, in the new Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) we are setting up:

. . . the new AWC will have a role as a market facilitator and will act as a catalyst to ensure that the market is operating as efficiently as possible. As part of the function of encouraging the Australian wool industry to adopt plans for the improvement of the marketing of Australian wool, the Corporation will be required to encourage the adoption of sale by description.

The Corporation, according to the second reading speech, is required to encourage the adoption of sale by description. Why would one do this? Unless one wanted to move down the road of acquisition, there is no great requirement for sale by description; it is a decision that should be made, not imposed on it-or even encouraged to be imposed on it-by an industry driven by industry demand. It is the sort of thing in this Bill which leads me to fear that here we have the beginning of another bureaucracy.

Given the people who ran the last bureaucracy, believe me, they will seek to make this a bureaucracy such as they had before. If Australian woolgrowers want innovation in wool marketing and to ensure they get the best results for their money, they should not put their faith in the Australian Wool Corporation or in agro-political bodies; they should send their money to the wool marketing reform group in Western Australia, which I believe has had the best ideas and has been consistent in its approach to the necessary wool industry reforms.

I turn now to the 15 per cent tax, which I believe will be hard to bear. The tax is broken into three components: debt management, promotion, and research and development (R&). The debt management component comprises 11 per cent; promotion comprises 3.5 per cent; and R& comprises 0.5 per cent. We have heard much from the Opposition about reducing this component to as low as 10 per cent. It says that it could perhaps be done for 12 per cent. This is not the problem facing the wool industry. It will not make much difference whether it is reduced by 3 per cent, 4 per cent or even 5 per cent; it has to be reduced much more dramatically than that. The Bill contains nothing to stop that happening should the opportunity arise. It can still be done. I will speak presently about how I believe it can be done.

It is pointless for the Opposition to come in here and talk about reducing the tax by that small amount. The Opposition harps a lot about what I call the `McLachlan flock reduction program'. The Opposition's proud boast is that 11 million sheep were slaughtered under the old scheme. Certainly 11 million sheep were slaughtered, but the question must be asked: how many would or should have been slaughtered anyway? Certainly a large percentage of that 11 million. There was a bizarre scheme where all woolgrowers paid the bureaucracy, which in turn paid to some woolgrowers, money for destroying the sheep, which is what every woolgrower should have done anyway and had a responsibility to do. It was a nonsense scheme; a mass flock slaughter scheme simply would not work.

TALK.START.PARA: —It did work.

—It did not work and the honourable member for Barker knows it did not work; it was based on the model of the gentleman farmer. I would say it has been a long time since that particular gentleman farmer has had his hands in the wool.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the problems of getting rid of the wool clip, a scheme is available to put the wool into zero coupon bonds. This will have the capacity to reduce the tax from 15 per cent to the very low level of 4 per cent, just for the components of research and development and promotion. I believe it is a program that will work and I am very pleased that the new Minister has undertaken to have it thoroughly researched. Opposition to this program comes from two main areas. Some people say, `The wool might fall into the hands of individuals who would then control the Australian flock'. That is possible but highly improbable, and the industry could not be any worse off than it is now anyway. Other people say, `If the worst came to the worst, at the end of 10 years the Government would owe some money'. That is also possible but highly improbable, and given that everyone agrees-including the Opposition-that the price of wool will rise it is certainly a risk worth taking now to get that large burden from around the necks of growers.
I find it deplorable that I have 10 minutes to speak on such important Bills and I rather resent the fact that Opposition members had 20 minutes, particularly when they had so little to say.

There has been enormous waste in research and development in the past. I believe it is essential that research and development be kept out of the hands of the Wool Corporation. When the scandals are eventually unearthed and we know the full ramifications of what the Wool Corporation did with the Abel Star handpiece, when I was in the industry 20 years ago, that handpiece was going to revolutionise the wool industry and remove the prevalence of second cuts in wool, which gives farmers one of their greatest areas of loss. This machine certainly did that; it was very effective. It is outrageous that in 20 years we did not see it go into full production, yet we saw the Wool Corporation spend millions of woolgrowers' dollars trying to circumvent the handpiece and get its favourites to develop a comparable scheme.

I would also like to look at wool testing. The Australian Wool Testing Authority (AWTA) submitted to the Vines Committee of Inquiry into the Wool Industry and the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council that it should have a monopoly on wool testing and that it alone should test Australia's wool clip. The AWTA tests by an airflow device, which is technology from the 1940s; all it does is measure the average fibre diameter of any particular sample.

Melden Laboratories, on the other hand, has developed, with it own resources, without help from the Australian Wool Corporation, a machine that not only tests-it gives the average fibre diameter-but also gives a print-out of the fibre diameter of 2,000 samples and enables one to have a much better idea of the disposition of the diameter in any particular sample of wool. This is important because of the tail. One could possibly get, as in South America, nominally 19- micron wool, which has some very broad fibres in it as well. Clearly a fibre with more consistency is much better for the industry. That is what is called style. It is one of the great things about Australian wool and one of the things that is very hard to test for under the proposed testing methods that the Corporation wants to impose on the industry.

It is interesting to note that the AWTA spent $8m of woolgrowers' money in developing this without success. It has been developed on a shoestring by Melden Laboratories, which is exporting that technology to the world today. I could go on with some of the other outrageous performances of the Australian Wool Corporation. I think of the then wool fibre marketing director, Mr Sven Andersen, traipsing around Europe, wreaking havoc as he went and I think of Mr Fletcher Jones's proposal to sell a million bales of wool in the United States. In 1990, he was going to save the industry by putting wool into men's slacks in America. We eventually sold 2,000 bales, with promotional costs of some $70m-odd, which works out to a promotional cost of about $430 a kilogram. That is a great effort.

We must ensure that those people who wreaked havoc on the industry before, and those people who are responsible for much of the trouble we have today, are not allowed to once more insinuate themselves into these new boards that are being set up. I urge the Minister to take care of that. I also urge the Minister in passing to be aware of those who come with their preconceived ideas. I know that the bureaucracy in his Department is very strong and very confident in its own knowledge. I suspect that what the Minister will get from Mr Miller, the Secretary to the Department, is very much what we have had in the past. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian wool industry is unique and the product produced is unique. No other industry is more important to the economy of Australia and to the standard of living of all Australians. Its viability is critical to thousands of woolgrowers, their families, rural towns and cities and the communities they serve.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation, introduced by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) does not provide the best option to restore that viability and confidence to the wool industry. The Government has not responded with a desire or a compassion commensurate with the significance of the issues, but clearly with the aim to limit, even preclude, any possibility of further government support. This legislation further exposes the Government's inept handling of the crisis that, for a myriad of reasons, has developed during the past 18 months.

In November 1970, during a period of depressed wool prices and markets, the coalition Government introduced the original reserve price scheme. The scheme was designed to smooth price fluctuations, not to maintain a minimum price. It was managed by the Australian Wool Commission, which, by the end of the 1970-71 season, had purchased nearly 600,000 bales, which were ultimately sold at a profit. The scheme was funded through the Government's credit facility at rural credit rates of interest. In 1973, under an ALP Government, the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) was established. A minimum reserve price was introduced in 1974. At that time, prices were low and stocks accumulated. Originally the floor price was underpinned with a government guarantee, but ultimately this was financed by growers through a wool levy, AWC trading profits and interests on investments. In June 1990, the AWC commercial borrowings were guaranteed by the Government.

At the commencement of the scheme, the legislation gave the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy responsibility for key decisions and the AWC administered them. This included the minimum price scheme. These roles were subsequently changed and the Wool Marketing Act 1987, which gave responsibility to the Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool Council of Australia for the management and day to day running of the industry. The Government's role therefore became one of general overseeing and direction. I mention these changes because I see them as crucial in any debate on the operation and success of statutory marketing authorities. It is important that we recognise that the objectives of the reserve price scheme changed from one that protected growers against disastrously low prices, with some protection against short term market falls, to the objective of attaining the maximum sustainable price.

In the context of this legislation, the reasons why the scheme was suspended and now abandoned should be documented. In 1983-84, the stockpile reached 1.6 million bales. As a result, private buyers and processors let their stocks run down. Wool demand increased during the 1980s from China, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) and Japan, which virtually eliminated that stockpile. Panic buying by the trade in 1987-88 caused a rapid increase in price. The minimum reserve price was increased from 408c a kilogram clean in 1986-87 to 870c a kilogram clean in 1988-89. This was a 70 per cent rise. In 1989-90, severe economic problems developed in the USSR and China, causing a 50 per cent reduction in their purchases. Those two countries accounted for 20 per cent of Australian wool exports in the important mid-micron range of our clip. The Australian dollar rose and wool production and supply increased through price expectations and excellent seasons.

I doubt if any industry has ever had to contend with a combination of such difficult circumstances. When these factors, many outside the influence of the woolgrower, occurred at a time of unsustainable high interest rates, introduced by that outstanding combination of Hawke and Keating, the devastation was obvious and predictable. Few commentators acknowledged the horrible impact of these monetary policies in the context of rural industry policy.

The industry was in deep trouble. The $1.8 billion support fund built up by growers was gone and the AWC had to borrow heavily to finance the stockpile at the market indicator of 870c. The Minister lowered the floor price to 700c for 1990-91, repudiating his own undertaking, destroying market confidence and increasing speculation within the trade. This decision sounded the death knell for the reserve price scheme.

The Government then endorsed some of the AWC's business plans, which included a maximum wool tax of up to 30 per cent, a possible surcharge on the wool tax up to 20 per cent for 1991-92, a 15 to 20 million sheep slaughter scheme, reduction in the maximum sale offerings from 170,000 to 140,000 bales per week, plus the most bizarre of all unworkable wool marketing suggestions, wool quotas. While all this was happening, the bulk of the woolgrowers had little information and little understanding of the position of their industry. I publicly stated, as many others did in the coalition, that we could not support an effective wool tax of 50 per cent or quotas. It seemed obvious that such taxes would fall heavily on the most efficient and viable producers left to repay industry debt as hundreds of other growers drifted into bankruptcy.

Finally, the whole situation fell to pieces when, on 1 February, the AWC suspended wool sales. On 11 February, the Minister suspended the reserve price scheme for the rest of the season and introduced measures designed to carry the AWC and growers through to the end of June. These included the 25 per cent levy and the supplementary payment scheme.

I now turn to this legislation, a package of nine Bills that relate to new administrative and management structures and the imposition of a wool tax at the rate of 15 per cent. I do not intend to comment on the new structures. They have already been discussed by my colleague the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). My major concern is with the level of the levy and the options available to manage the $2.7 billion debt and the 4.7 million bale stockpile held by the Australian Wool Corporation.
I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table relating to the coalition's proposals for a 10 per cent levy. I have already received the permission of the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to take part in this debate on the five cognate Bills before the House, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill, the Australian Wool Corporation Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill, the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill and the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills. I would like to address them in general terms and perhaps to make some comment on the figures that the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), and the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), have given with regard to the projected incomes of wool farmers for 1991-92 and onwards. If they could substantiate a little more the creative accounting that has gone into those figures, I would be very glad to pass more comment on them; but I will return to them at a later date.

SPEECH.PARA: In rising to address the House on the package of Bills relating to the future of the wool industry in Australia, I am aware of the great heartache that has accompanied the debate within the industry as its members seek to come to terms with the problems-not of their own making-in an industry which has been Australia's staple for so long. Although the wool industry is not represented to any extent in my electorate of Richmond, for climatic reasons, I have followed closely the debate.

The problems associated with the wool industry might appear to the casual observer to be quite different from the problems of the export oriented primary industries represented in my electorate or in the coastal electorates. However, they have a number of things in common. Among these are the events of overseas which of recent years have affected our export markets. Although it will bring no comfort to woolgrowers, they are fortunate that they have not had to deal also with the subsidised dumping by the European Community and the United States of America. That dumping has plagued our primary industries and has brought the Uruguay Round of talks to a halt. However, that is cold comfort for the wool industry which has other unique problems to deal with.

The Bills before this House can quite rightly be called a comprehensive recovery plan for the wool industry which will reform the administration of the wool industry when they come into force. The comprehensive plan for the wool industry broadly does two things; firstly, it allows the industry to retain control over its own destiny and, secondly, it underscores the continued support of the Australian Government for that industry.

In his second reading speech, the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, now Treasurer (Mr Kerin), recognised and acknowledged the importance of the wool industry both to the Australian rural economy and as the main agricultural contributor to Australia's export income. The measures before this House tonight also acknowledge that importance and contribution. They also deal with what has been called, without exaggeration, the biggest crisis the wool industry has faced in modern times. That crisis stems from the major adjustment to market prices which the industry must make while at the same time dealing with the tremendous burden of debt and a huge stockpile of wool which almost defies imagination.

The structures which will flow from the package of Bills now before the House will provide the efficient administrative oversight to allow these problems to be dealt with, and they must be dealt with in the interests of those whose livelihood depends upon finding solutions and in the interests of the wider Australian community.

It is appropriate for this House to recognise the contribution which the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has made to this nation through his work in this portfolio not only for the wool industry but also for other primary industries which are vital for the future of this nation. He sits there, working away quietly at the table. The esteem with which he is held by people right across the political spectrum who have had dealings with him in his portfolio is equalled by few.

The Minister never sought to find slick solutions nor to be a crowd pleaser just for the sake of political gain, but was seen to be what we all recognise by the term `fair dinkum' in his pursuit of the best possible directions for Australian primary industries. While some of those working in the various primary industries might not always have agreed with him, it would be true to say that he held the respect of all of rural Australia.

Indeed, I reveal for the record that a well-known National Party of Australia figure on the north coast-actually from the Page electorate-not long after I was elected to this House, said to me, `Whatever you do, don't let them take away John Kerin. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I declare my interest, as I rise tonight, as a woolgrower with an electorate in Queensland-the electorate of Maranoa-with a substantial stake in the wool industry and the future of the wool industry. The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill, which is before the House, is significant in that it will either make or break many woolgrowers in Australia, and it will make them if our amendment is agreed to by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean).

SPEECH.PARA: Before moving on to the Bill, I notice that we have with us tonight at the table the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, now the new Treasurer (Mr Kerin), and I wish him well in that role. I hope that, following his statement on the Australian dollar being too high, he may have some influence on the Australian dollar and bring it back to more realistic levels.

I do not have the same confidence, nor does much of rural Australia, in the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, because he has an image problem to overcome; he has got to lose some of the spots that he gained during the broad comb dispute-or, I should say, the narrow comb dispute-the live sheep trade dispute and also the Mudginberri dispute. So he has a huge image problem to overcome, and I am sure, for the sake of the Minister at the table, that he will try to overcome that. Let us hope so, for the sake of Australia.

I would like to pass on my congratulations, and have them recorded in Hansard, to the Chairman-elect of the Australian Wool Corporation. Mr Mac Drysdale, who has been appointed by the Minister, is in fact a constituent of mine. I have known him quite well and I am sure that he is going to do a tremendous job in that role. It is also interesting to note that the electorate of Maranoa will in fact have supplied the Australian wool industry, when Mac takes up his position, with two chairmen of the Australian Wool Corporation, the former one from the electorate of Maranoa being Sir William Gunn.

I think it is fitting that we should reflect on the last 18 months. The industry itself, the growers out there, and Australians generally owe a debt of gratitude to the staff of the Australian Wool Corporation. In the last 18 months they have been through a most difficult time. This time last year, they were buying 70 per cent of our Australian woolclip, and some days more than that. They had to store that wool, pay for it and in many cases ship it overseas. In November, the industry called on them to set up a quota scheme. With all the debate raging at the time, they had to field calls on what would happen with the quotas, how the quotas would apply. Then in December they had to set up a flock reduction scheme and in February of this year they had to set up a deficiency scheme which expires at the end of June this year.

The Wool Corporation staff have had an enormous load on their shoulders and I do not believe we have heard any of them complain once. I believe that the industry owes a debt of gratitude for the wonderful work that they have done in these most difficult times. The staffing levels would not have been set up to cope with the sort of crisis that has faced the industry in the last 12 months.

But let us look at the minimum reserve price scheme. This is an historic night, perhaps particularly for the National Party, because it was the National Party that introduced this legislation 18 years ago. If it was not for the legislation of the now Treasurer and former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, this reserve price scheme could still be operating today. I believe that is the pity of what we face right now in Australia-that the reserve price is not operating today at around 450c or 500c a kilogram. If it had been, we would never have seen the stockpiles that we are confronted with or seen taxes that reached 25 per cent and were proposed to reach 35 per cent this year. Those are the things that I believe will be a legacy that the former Minister, now the Treasurer, will have to live with.

Under our legislation, the minimum reserve price scheme would have been operating right now at today's prices, not at prices of 12 or 18 months ago. Our figures, which support a 10 per cent tax-no more than 10 per cent for the coming 12 months-are in fact credible figures, as the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has said. But what underlies those figures is the sale of non-wool assets-$120m of them in the next 12 months. I-and I believe most members on this side of the House-believe that we must ensure that that sale happens, because 70 per cent of those non-wool assets of the Corporation do not store any wool; they are readily saleable and are returning good returns on the capital invested. I would rather see those assets sold than see woolgrowers sold up in the next 12 months.

Let us look at the figures of the former Minister, now the Treasurer, who is at the table tonight. Perhaps we should call him the Minister for negative incomes, because he said a negative income of a few hundred dollars is not really substantial and he said at the Australian Wool Council meeting that the difference between 12 per cent and 15 per cent amounted to 12c. But he failed to say that it was 12c a kilogram. When one multiplies that out, one gets a substantial amount of money, not an insignificant amount of money.

The difference between our proposal and the Government's proposal, the difference between 10 per cent and 15 per cent, equates to $700 for every 1,000 sheep. That equates to $120m in woolgrowers' accounts around Australia from 1 July next year. That is the difference between our proposals: $120m. If one looks at today's closing figure of 574c, the amount will be almost $150m. I believe that would create jobs and assist growers out there to survive. At a time of record unemployment, I thought the Government would be looking at trying to keep people in rural Australia. It has always protected the jobs of unionists and I thought it might have been looking at a way of keeping people out there in rural Australia-keeping jobs and keeping people on the land.

I know we do not have the responsible Minister at the table, but the former Minister could nod his head if he agrees that 10 per cent is right. That is all he would have to do as Treasurer-nod his head and say that 10 per cent is the goer. I challenge him to nod that head tonight. It really does not take much. The new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy would certainly make a name for himself straight away, and perhaps gain a bit of credibility out there in the bush, if he nodded his head, if he were here tonight, and if he showed some interest in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is called Noddy.

—He will probably be called more than Noddy by the time his term expires. The $120m will be critical in the next 12 months because many dedicated woolgrowers are facing bankruptcy and the $120m could well be the difference between families keeping food on the table or keeping their children at school; it could well be the difference between survival and, at the end of the next 12 months, being both penniless and homeless.
—Simply by selling the Corporation assets first.

—That is all it requires, as the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), says, to bring the tax down to 10 per cent. These are significant figures. That $120m would be indeed valuable to those growers out there tonight-and I believe many of them will be listening to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the House take the longer term view. We are not taking the short term view, as is the Government. As the honourable member for Murray, the Deputy Leader of the National Party, said, our figures have been run through and through, and through again. They are credible; they stand up. They will meet the Government's debt repayment scheme. I ask the Treasurer, who is at the table, to nod his head in agreement.

My time is short because of the guillotine and I know a lot of other people in the House would like to talk, but exemptions are proposed in the Bill and I would like to say that exempting carpet wools from the tax proposals is not the right way to go. Once we create an exemption, other sectors have just as good a reason to be exempted. I refer to the Sharlee wool industry, the very fine end of the wool industry. That includes the people who shed their sheep and produce 16 and 17 micron wools. They have a very small industry and produce a very small quantity of wool annually. They market that direct to mills. There is none of that in the stockpile and, as we know, there are 11,000 bales of carpet wool in the stockpile. But carpet wools have been exempted. I ask the Minister why the Sharlee woolgrowers have not been exempted.

I know the industry will survive, and I for one do not believe that we need fewer growers in Australia. I believe that in the next four or five years we will see the great wool industry emerge again and that it will rise to be our number one export earner again if the right decision is taken tonight. That right decision will be to support the Opposition's amendment for a 10 per cent tax.

The purpose of our amendments is to put the bureaucracy under pressure and oblige it not to squander grower money.

As the honourable member for Kalgoorlie said, and as other honourable members have pointed out, on the proposal of the 15 per cent, the debt servicing portion of it should be 11 per cent, promotion 3.5 per cent and research and development 0.5 per cent. The point the Opposition makes is that the debt servicing obligation has already been reduced because the market has realised better than people anticipated; so the outstanding debt sits at $2.63 billion, which was the amount projected to be reached in 1992-93. Along with the asset sales already outlined by the honourable member for Mallee and the honourable member for Maranoa, this makes it possible for the Opposition to responsibly suggest that the growers should be saddled with a tax bill of no more than 10 per cent.

We are talking about dealing with the growers' money, and we are obliging the growers to part with more than they need in the face of what for them may be the difference between bankruptcy and survival. You know, Mr Deputy Speaker, because it is legendary, that the Australian wool industry is an efficient industry. Of the operators, 93 per cent are family based. In fact, if we take primary industry across Australia in total, over the last 25 years primary industry has seen its costs go up by 690 per cent while the price received for its product has gone up by a mere 316 per cent. A measure of its sufficiency is the fact that farmers have survived under this sort of pressure.

We are proposing to put some pressure on the new bodies being established to manage the Australian wool industry. Those bodies are, for the sake of the record, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, which will be responsible for the disposal of the stockpile; the Australian Wool Research and Development Corporation, which will obviously be responsible for research and development; the Australian Wool Corporation, which has been restructured so that it is responsible principally for promotion of standards and industry training; and the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council, which will replace the old Australian Wool Council and become a key advisory body to the Government.

Our call is that these bodies be obliged-in fact, forced-to taper their costs because the growers' returns are being desperately tapered. I do not wish to take up any more time of the House than is absolutely necessary because many others wish to participate in the debate. However, I do want to take up the point made by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), when he came into this chamber and, in a convenient throwaway line, accused the Opposition of what he called `creative accounting'. He said, `If this is not the case, I would like to look at the figures again'. I thought that that was the height of audacity. When did we receive the Bills with which we are currently dealing? We received them late on Thursday night last week--

TALK.START.PARA: —At 2 a.m. in the morning.

—Yes, in the morning. It has put real demands on the staff of the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray and on the staff of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), one of whom is in the gallery tonight, to come up with figures that would stand up. I make the point to the honourable member for Richmond that the figures that the Opposition is dealing with are responsible figures designed to enable the maximum number of woolgrowers in Australia to survive.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government had exercised precisely the same sort of responsibility, both in the development of figures and historically, in allowing, as the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) pointed out, income equalisation deposits to continue, we would not have this disastrous debate in the Parliament tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister table their figures?

It could be that we should add a margin. Indeed, that has always been my past preference. In particular, I see no reason why, where there are shortfalls of wool, as I understand, for example, there were in carbonised wools, we could not sell such wool from overseas stores so that it would be available. I can tell the Minister that, as far as I am concerned, the family farmers in my part of the world would far prefer a fire sale of the AWC's assets than a fire sale of their own.

We are told by farmers that they have had to withdraw their children from school, that they are no longer able to buy clothing or the prerequisites to operate their farms because of the collapse of the reserve price mechanism and the problems in marketing the clip. Let us forget about trying to get the highest possible price for what I would see as being highly negotiable assets in terms of wool stores which at the moment are yielding something like 14 per cent in rental payments.

I am concerned about the contrast between the annual reporting provisions of the Australian Wool Corporation Bill 1991 and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that in clause 89 (3) on page 39 of the Australian Wool Corporation Bill there is reference to the fact that there is an obligation to lay before the House with respect to the Australian Wool Corporation annual reports of the Corporation. That gives an opportunity to the Parliament, if it wishes, to terminate that notice by virtue of a regulation. I understand that this is the way which the legislation will be applied. If we contrast that with what is contained in the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill, we will see that there is a series of areas in which directions can be given by the Minister. For example, under clause 32 (1) the Commission must, as soon as possible after 1 July 1991, prepare and give to the Minister a corporate plan relating to a period of five years commencing on that date. Under clause 33 there is a capacity for the Commission to be given a direction by the Minister. There is no obligation to publish it. If we look further, we find that the Minister can ask for additional information. Under clause 51 he can reject nominations to the Corporation.

I want the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission to report to the Minister regularly. I want any instructions and directions from the Minister to be reported to the woolgrowers and the public. If efforts are made to shield these directions under a cloud of bureaucracy that lies within the legislation, I fear for the industry.

This is a difficult time for the wool industry. All of us trust that the product of this legislation will be a brighter future. Indeed, I read with some sadness the conclusion of Hugh Beggs's annual report when he said:
Our major task in the year ahead is to restore confidence in the wool industry and in particular the important role played by the AWC.

I am not so worried about the important role played by the AWC. I am concerned about all dimensions of the wool industry-production, processing, distribution and, of course, meeting the requirements of the end customer. There are enormous challenges. We have to recognise that we cannot just produce and expect our customers to buy. We have to sell. We have to market. We have to understand that we are in a very competitive marketplace in terms of other fibres. For the life of me, when cotton is selling well, when we are talking about increasing the production of cotton, I find it anomalous that we are here discussing legislation because the wool industry is in the plight it is.

My own view is that the statistics of production will significantly change because of drought and weather conditions. The production levels this year are likely to be closer to 850 million kilograms than the 900 million kilograms that has been projected by the Minister. As a result, I believe that the industry will be in a much better state this time next year than it is now. But it will be no fault of the Minister and no fault of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) for his attendance here this evening. Something that I have always welcomed about his particular involvement is that whenever there is a debate in this House he is the sole Labor Minister who chooses to sit throughout the debate and, to my knowledge, has always done so. SPEECH.PARA: I want to bring a short one-liner to the Treasurer's attention-it is one that I use frequently-`There are no such things as political solutions to commercial problems'. Unfortunately, in this wool legislation we see another attempt to apply the political solution. In fact, nothing has changed. We even have a form of reserve price scheme, because the Australian Wool Realisation Commission will be fiddling the market because it has no proper guidelines laid down in legislation within which it will operate. We have all the old quangos; we have just given them some new names and broken them up into different groups. The Wool Realisation Commission will be required to maximise the value of each of its sales. The announcement of an annual debt reduction target, together with a known rate of tax, will enable the market to make an estimate of the sales required from the stockpile to meet the target.

I remind the Treasurer of something else that occurred during this wool debate and which I will never forget. That is why it fell over. We all knew it. Why the heck are we trying to resurrect it in this peculiar way? Why are we continuing to impose all of these substantial costs on woolgrowers, who would prefer to do it-and, I think, now understand that it is best to do it-in their own way?

Figures have been thrown around, such as the operating cost of the Australian Wool Corporation of $45m a year. That $45m would go a long way towards supporting woolgrower's families around Australia. I think that is more important.

The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill gives us the Wool Realisation Commission. But before it has even been formed, the Minister decided to throw 100,000 bales of wool into the marketplace. TALK.START.PARA: —How many did they sell?
—I am not sure; it did not sell much.

—It was 11,000 bales or something like that. One minute the Corporation is in there and the next minute it is out of there. We do not know where it is going. It is on again and off again. The worst thing that can happen to the industry is to have people make decisions in that particular way.

SPEECH.PARA: The newly formed AWC will have responsibilities for promotion, standards and industry training. It is even going to have an annual general meeting for those people who can afford to go. I do not know where we will find them. What a farce! If we are going to have some control over these people, why can we not have a proper plebiscite and a proper vote and let people do it from the convenience of their homes?
