Within this group of quangos we will have the Australian Wool Research and Development Corporation. If as a woolgrower-which I admit I am-I am prepared to pay a tax, it is probably to aid in research, particularly if it is carefully allocated with some reasonable consideration. For many years the researchers sat in judgment as to who got the money. I am not sure all of it went to a good cause.

I wish to make a remark concerning the International Wool Secretariat (IWS), which will come under the control of the AWC in terms of its promotion of product, and research. The other day I bought a woollen doona. I wonder how many honourable members listening tonight, or anyone who may be listening to the radio broadcast tonight, even knew that they could buy a woollen doona. It is an excellent product. It uses the coarser end of our micron range of wool. It is an invention of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). In other words, it represents a very practical use of taxes paid in the past. However, as I have just pointed out, no-one knows that woollen doonas are for sale. The reason I was able to buy one is that I rang the CSIRO, who put me onto the manufacturer in Victoria, who was then able to tell me that there are three shops in Perth which stock them. It is a tiny little franchise operation called Mrs Mouse. Not one major retailer is stocking those doonas or the pillows that we can buy also. I hope to get some of them to put in my motel because I think they will be better than the crummy pillows I sleep on around Australia.

The CSIRO has managed to mould polyester and wool together, not just as a mixture stirred up in a pot, but by getting them to fix to one another in a cross-formation to maintain a springiness which, as we know, wool is not otherwise able to achieve over time as it packs down. I am living very comfortably under my woollen doona in Perth. I would expect that everybody with a commitment to the industry, including the Treasurer, would go out and buy one. The real requirement is that Australians know that they are available. Where is the IWS, which will rake another $89m out of woolgrowers this season so that it can spend $187m? I do not think it knows that these woollen doonas exist. I think that organisation is a waste of money. I would not give it a penny, because it cannot even promote this product.

There are tens of thousands of doonas sold every year in Europe and in the colder countries. We are still letting Thai feathers fill them, yet we have a product in Australia which would use the higher micron wool found in most of that stockpile. The manufacturers are using the higher micron wool, but they could probably use the very coarse micron wool.

Wool has other features; for instance, it is much more absorbent of fluids. The CSIRO tells me that when people sleep they exude up to seven litres of fluid a night. Those people would be much more comfortable and healthy under a wool doona. Where is the IWS? One of the worst things about this legislation is that it will continue to tax woolgrowers at 3.5 per cent-$89m-while adding reserves and other costs so that the Corporation can spend $187m on the IWS.

Like the AWC, the greatest effort of promotion by the IWS, as I have learned to my great annoyance, was for itself. The IWS has managed to convince Australian woolgrowers and us politicians that it is a useful organisation; it simply is not. Let me give the House the best example I can: the IWS almost wrung its hands in apology to us for being so successful in convincing Australians and the world to buy lightweight wool that it had neglected our coarser wool production, and that is why-through its success-public attention turned to fine micron wools to the consequent neglect of the coarser micron wool, which was a substantial part of Australian wool production.

That happens to be a load of absolute rubbish. During the time the IWS spent all its money promoting lightweight wool, that product was the result of technological change in the cloth production industry. As I discovered from papers unrelated to promotion, the simple fact is that in recent times the wool weaving industry has gone from looms that operated at 120 picks a minute, which means that the bobbin went across the loom 120 times a minute, to looms that operate at 480 picks a minute.

There were other reasons, such as natural economies: whereas one worker could look after six of those slower looms, today he must look after twelve of the faster looms. If the thread breaks, the principal job of the worker is to rejoin it and get the machine running again. It turns out that a piece of wool yarn, whereas it used to be able to break once every two kilometres of yarn, can now break only once every 16 kilometres of yarn. How is that achieved? By weaving more wool fibres into the same thickness of wool-in fact, 90-because union is strength. That means that producers of cloth must buy finer wool and the industry must adjust to that, other than in areas such as the manufacture of doonas and so on, which should be able to consume all our coarser wools at the drop of a hat.

The IWS did nothing to achieve that situation; it was a natural progression through the manufacturing industry, and the IWS fraudulently presented itself as achieving all this when it had done absolutely nothing. Tonight we allow the Council to continue to fund that organisation-the enemies of the industry. It must stop and we must ask ourselves whether we need the IWS. I understand the American cotton industry does some promotion and raises a levy; I was told that by the Wool Council so I presume I can believe it, although I tend to put the Council alongside the Prime Minister in more recent times, in terms of integrity and honesty. However, the reality is that the American cotton industry does not pay a levy in Australia, and everybody buys cotton. Why? Because it is well promoted. Who promotes cotton? The Levi-Strauss (Aust) Pty Ltd company does; it is a manufacturer and is close to the market; it will produce the product and promote it. Yet we continue to load the actual producing industry.

Finally, like others, I recognise that there are time constraints tonight. I deplore the guillotine which reduces the opportunity for the Opposition to draw some of these facts to the attention of Government members in the hope that they might do something about them, although, as I have said time and time again, there is a fair chance that a mob of socialists will want to intervene in everything, and that is what this legislation is doing. I inform the Treasurer that the evidence is that a 15 per cent tax is not needed and is a rip-off. The Opposition has produced the evidence without the help of banks of computers or staff from Treasury and or the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, because it is simple arithmetic. It is easy to see, as others have said, that if the Government is prepared to start the wind-down of Wool Corporation assets it can do so easily and can guarantee survival for the people who matter most-the people who grow wool.

The reason the wool industry is in this bind is the procrastination and stupidity of politicians, both agro-politicians-who are still queuing up for a job and a few overseas trips-and parliamentary politicians. Consequently, we must bear some of the burden of responsibility. I was amazed when in Question Time this afternoon someone wanted to know why Queensland is not getting a bigger share of the largess of the Australia Council-$40m or $50m spread around Australia so that someone can go to some show that no-one would pay the right money to see in a fit. There is simple evidence to show whether something is popular: people will pay their own money. The Government does not have to subsidise the Phantom of the Opera or a State of Origin league game or a football game. It is funny how the Labor blokes keep subsidising the opera while taxing the football; I have never been able to work that out.

The simple fact is that if the Government is short of money to help woolgrowers because 10 per cent does not add up-and I am sure it would-it should get a bit from the Australia Council, because I am sure that the people out on the farms need that money more than a few ballet dancers. Thousands of millions of dollars have been wasted in that regard because we have all these champagne socialists in the Australian Labor Party today who prefer the opera to saving an industry like the wool industry.

Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the time you have given me. I thank my colleagues for not asking me to sit down more quickly, but I hope that honourable members have listened to some of the points I have made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the stance of the coalition, which is that the wool tax should be placed at a maximum of 10 per cent or at a lesser amount set by regulation as circumstances permit. I feel that 10 per cent is the absolute maximum that growers can sustain at the moment and remain viable. I believe strongly that the tax should be as low as possible for the first one or two years at least so that financially stressed farmers can get through the difficult couple of years that they are now facing, at least partly due to the `recession that we had to have'. I regret that the Government wants the tax level to be at 15 per cent and I also regret the fact that the Australian Wool Council (AWC) wanted the tax at 12 per cent, although I was told just a moment ago that it may have come back to 10 per cent; I hope that is correct. The Opposition's calculations show that the tax can be placed at 10 per cent and are based on a number of assumptions, both factual ones or quite conservative ones.

SPEECH.PARA: These assumptions are based on the fact that the AWC debt is at $2.63 billion. These assumptions have allowed for the fact that there is a $200m interest free loan for the first couple of years and for the fact that the stockpile will stand from 1 July at 815 million kilograms, or 4.4 million bales, which incidentally is more than double the previous historical figures of 1.8 million bales and 1.6 million bales. It also assumes that the AWC reserves and the general account will be $30m, that the promotion account will be $114m and that there will be $56m in the research and development (R&) account.

The AWC assets have been conservatively valued at $290m-it is better to sell what one can of these assets rather than sell out farmers-and it also assumes that wool production for the next financial year, 1991-92, will be 875 million kilograms, and that the AWC can borrow at the long term bond rate guaranteed at 10.75 per cent. It also allows for the sale of 25 million kilograms of wool from the stockpile next year, that the cost of storing the stockpile and running the AWC will amount to $45m, that the AWC expenditure in 1991-92 will be $187m, plus $54m for R&, and that wool will be selling at 450c per kilogram clean.

At the moment, wool is selling at about 580c, so that is a fairly conservative estimate. That comes out, after allowing for running costs of $567m and revenue income of $435m, at a shortfall of $132m, which means that growers would have to be levied 5.1 per cent at 450c a kilogram to service that $132m. If 4 per cent is added for promotion and R&, that comes out at a levy of 9.1 per cent-somewhat under the 10 per cent that we are asking for as a maximum. That, of course, does not take into account that a flock reduction scheme could also be put in place on top of this and the percentage needed being lowered even further, down as low as 5 per cent or less.

The Australian Labor Party wants a tax of 15 per cent, that to be made up of 11 per cent for debt management; 3.5 per cent for promotion, which is about 20c per kilogram; and 0.5 per cent for R&-a total of 15 per cent. They are the figures.

I want to comment on a few matters that other speakers have not commented on. I support the recommendation that the carpet wool growers be exempted from the debt management level and that they will be paying 4 per cent. I understand that carpet wool is defined as wool in excess of 32 microns. They will pay a 4 per cent levy; in other words, 3.5 per cent for promotion and 0.5 per cent for R&. I point out that they already pay a 6 per cent levy-their own industry levy-which is used for marketing. In total, carpet woolgrowers will be paying 10 per cent. If they had been asked to pay 15 per cent, it would have meant that they would be paying 15 per cent, plus their own 6 per cent levy-a 21 per cent levy-which would have meant that there would be no industry in carpet wool. That would have been a great shame because we import $100m of carpet wool each year into this country, mainly from New Zealand.

It is a remarkable fact that, even though Australia exports most of the wool that it produces, most of the wool that is used within Australia is actually imported. The carpet wool producers have not been receiving any supplementary payments since that scheme was put in place some months ago. It is interesting to note that when the reserve price scheme was lowered from 870c a kilogram to 700c, a drop of about 19 per cent, the medullated carpet wools were only lowered by the AWC by 8.8 per cent and the filler carpet wools were only lowered by 13 per cent. That made them relatively higher priced than they were before that drop took place. That made the reserve price scheme for these types of wool the dearest in the world, and it made those types of wool unsaleable. The reasons why that was done are quite beyond me.

Carpet Wool Marketers Ltd has already purchased the speciality or medullated wool at a considerable loss to itself. Much of that wool was poorly classed and described within the stockpile. It has offered the AWC to buy the filler wools. The letters that were written to the AWC were not answered. I understand that the letters were written to David Clarke, who will head the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, offering to buy the 14,558 bales of wool there over an 18-month period. I hope that he answers that letter and takes up that offer; I think it is a good one.

I want to make some short comments about the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who I note is not in the chamber tonight. If he is going to do what he said on the steps of Parliament House this morning he would do, I would have thought that he would have shown an interest in the industry. The very least he could do is to start learning something about the industry and be here tonight. I note that the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and now Treasurer (Mr Kerin), to his credit, is here and I thank him for that. However, the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has spent all his life opposing what farmers stand for and what they aspire to. He has devoted his career to having people paid higher wages for less work, maintaining rorts and idle time and all those types of things. As I remember, he opposed the loading of live sheep; he opposed the introduction of wide combs into the wool industry; and he opposed the Mudginberri abattoir wage deals which allowed higher wages for productivity increases. It is dreadful to think that this person, who has done all this, is now to oversee the rural industry.

On another matter, with the passage of time, I think we can say that we now all understand better what went wrong with the reserve price scheme that operated for 17 years in Australia in its present form. We all recognise that mistakes were made chasing fluctuating exchange rates in one direction and not the other. We all recognise that mistakes were made in placing the industry in a position of buying in large amounts of stocks during times of high interest rates. We all recognise that mistakes were made in massively increasing supply to a level above that which had ever been sold in this country, especially at a time of world downturn in textile demand. I acknowledge that there are still a handful of growers and others who believe that 870c per kilogram could have been sustained in the face of all this, but I think that most people in this country now recognise that this was fairyland stuff. Fortunately, growers will now get their market signals much more rapidly and accurately than before, and I am pleased to say that that ultimately will be to the benefit of the growers.

Wool is already priced higher in the market, in nominal terms, than it was before the last artificial price spike-that is a remarkable factor to contemplate-despite the massive oversupply that now exists and despite the overhang of the stockpile. The disposal methods of the stockpile, I believe, are crucial, and I particularly welcome the appointment to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission of someone of the calibre of David Clarke. I particularly welcome the wide range of financial skills that he has. It is imperative that the stockpile be disposed of in a transparent, a predictable and a proper manner-a manner that will cause minimal disruption to the coming markets, especially to the spring sales, which traditionally have been somewhat fragile. The viability of many growers in this country will depend on the success of the disposal of the stockpile. I believe that the Minister should assist this by keeping the wool tax down to a maximum of 10 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, we are debating this wool legislation under the guillotine, and those of us who have a longstanding interest-and I declare my interest as a woolgrower-are limited in the comments that we can make. In fact, with all the crisis that this $6 billion industry has been through, not once in the last six to nine months have we had a full and open debate on the industry in a calm atmosphere.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to see the Treasurer, the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), here in the House. I am disturbed that the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) is not with us because those of us in the wool industry well recall his contribution to the wool industry in the storemen and packers strike in the late 1970s. His great contribution on that occasion was to negotiate, like the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and at the end of the day he settled for such a big figure for those storemen and packers that the whole wool industry decided that it did not want any more of his members in the industry and most of the handling is now done by mechanical means. That was his contribution to the wool industry in those early days and I am not sure that he has learnt a lot since.

I agree with the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) that the attitudes of the new Minister have been totally contrary to the desires and aspirations of farmers throughout Australia. However, he has got some friends down in the electorate of Corangamite. If he wants to come down there, we will show him how the good sheep operators perform, where the best cattle are and how he might come to grips with rural Australia.

The fundamental issue before us is the level of taxes in this Bill. The coalition is quite clear that a 10 per cent tax is the way to go. We have had a range of taxes over the last 18 months during this whole wool debate. The Government is now suggesting a 15 per cent tax to overcome the accumulated debt problems. We have done our figures and we are recommending a 10 per cent tax and we will stick to it. I draw the attention of the House to the fact that the then Minister, the Australian Wool Council and the Australian Wool Corporation have been recommending taxes of up to 25 per cent. On one occasion they were even suggesting taxes of between 40 and 50 per cent if the necessity arose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus quotas.

—Plus quotas, which even the then Minister in his saner moments did not believe, and those of us who had been through the industry agreed that this could not happen. The AWC debt of about $2.7 billion is at present less than the $3.5 billion that most of us concerned with the wool industry thought might be the case. At least that has been an improvement. We have done our figures in relation to the debt servicing requirements, the reduction in research and development, the possible asset sales of the Wool Corporation, and the estimated price, which is anyone's guess, which has improved.

SPEECH.PARA: The stockpile of 815 million kilograms or 4.4 million bales is again a little more optimistic and better than estimated some six months ago. The other encouraging feature is the reduction in interest rates to about 10.75 per cent. I say in passing that the interest rates the Corporation is paying are a lot less than those being paid out by hard working farmers on their overdrafts at this stage.

The key question is this stockpile and the overhang that creates in the market. The important thing is that the coalition has agreed that the stockpile should be released by volume and that there should be a predictable, clear arrangement, as the honourable member for Parkes has suggested, in the way in which that stockpile should be released so that buyers and sellers, and the market generally, will know exactly where the 4 1/2 million bales will go in the marketplace.

As the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, would be aware, the wool industry is very happy with the fact that the stockpile will be held in quarantine until December 1991, allowing the current year's production to be sold in the first half of the selling season, which means that the larger volume will be sold in this half and then we can get on with getting rid of the stockpile. The interesting thing is that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said that the Corporation decided to sell 100,000 bales because it saw a rise in the market, demonstrating the great problem that Mr David Clarke and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission will have in the way in which they go about getting rid of the stockpile. Tactics cannot be changed halfway through the selling season because there is a lift in the market; they have to be clear and transparent. Only on that basis will we get rid of the stockpile.

It is worth noting that there has been a change in the wool price. Wool has been selling and moving in the pipeline. This is very much against the attitude of the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wool Council which had a view that wool would sell because it was a quality product and price was not a feature. That myth, that total unreality, has been smashed to the ground in recent weeks because when the price has been lowered a great amount of wool has been sold in the open market by auction. So, relative to the other fibres, cotton and synthetics, wool is now selling because its price is competitive. Buyers are coming back into the market for the first time in six or seven years because they can see a commodity from which they can make a profit.

The coalition, in drawing up its figures and suggesting this 10 per cent levy, has taken into account the lowering of interest rates, as I have suggested. The fact is that there is a very dry season throughout Australia and drought is looming in large parts of the wool growing areas. A number of ewes have not been joined, a number are not fat and therefore the lambing percentage will be lower. In my own judgment the sheep flock could even be down to as low as 150 million, which is a lot less than the 175 to 185 million sheep which it was estimated we had.

The stock reduction scheme, which a number of us on this side have been suggesting as a contributing factor to reducing the number of sheep, has helped. Some 10 to 12 million sheep have been taken away from the production cycle. That has helped to reduce the supply of Australian wool where the market has been oversupplied and we will get equality between supply and demand, and the price.

The cost of storing the stockpile and administering the Australian Wool Corporation-as the honourable member for O'Connor has said-is $45m. Some woolgrowers wonder whether they are getting value for money. The important thing in this stockpile reduction-the Government is allowing some seven years for it to be achieved-is balancing the Government's loan guarantee of $2.6 billion and getting that money back against the growers' returns. As we all know, growers are experiencing very difficult times and they are keen to get the highest price they can. If this stockpile flows onto the market in a haphazard manner, then all will be lost.

I draw attention to the fact that woolgrowers have lost $1.8 billion. I think that many people around Australia have overlooked that fact. I am confident that the Government's loan will be paid back in full, but the woolgrowers at this stage have lost that $1.8 billion and they do not have much hope of getting it back.

The setting up of these four statutory bodies and the accumulated debt at this stage sounds the death knell to any reserve price scheme ever being re-introduced. This buffer stock type scheme has been a total failure; it should never be contemplated again. It is worth recording that it was voted against by woolgrowers on two occasions and yet, by certain political manoeuvres, it was introduced through this Parliament. The floating exchange rate did not stabilise wool prices in purchasers' hands, as the honourable member for Parkes so rightly pointed out in his speech.

A buffer stock reserve price scheme will not work. It has proved to be a total failure. This Bill, and this debate, should be the end of any such suggestions by woolgrowers in the future. The introduction of further statutory bodies just gives the lie to the total free enterprise position of woolgrowers who are keen to sell their own wool in a private enterprise manner.

The new Australian Wool Corporation is trying to maintain quality, promotion and standards. My suggestion is that that should be done by a privatised woolgrower body, paid for by woolgrowers, away from government and political interference, so that woolgrowers can get on with their own industry and sell wool in their own way without relying on big brother corporation or big brother government to help them out in difficult times.

The one encouraging feature about the Australian Wool Realisation Commission is that in seven years, under this legislation, it will be removed by a sunset clause. Some of us hope that its job will be completed in four or five years. So at least there is something to remove it from the statute books. I, and the honourable member for O'Connor, have some reservations about the role of the Australian Wool Research and Development Corporation-yet another corporation-across the industry and its value to woolgrowers.

The advisory board, headed by Sir William Vines, is an indication of the lack of confidence by the Minister, the Government and many of us on this side of the House in the contribution by the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Woolgrowers Council. During the recent crisis, and due to poor advice, it got itself into a mess.

Finally, the wool industry should proceed, with no statutory corporations and no taxes, with an incentive to innovate and change and market wool for woolgrowers in an open market option system and move away from influence by agro-politicians and by members of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 30 seconds I have left to me, I give this message to the present Treasurer (Mr Kerin): the woolgrowers of the western division of New South Wales cannot pay a 15 per cent tax and remain viable. They had problems, before this tax was even intimated, with the extra costs and charges of government. They cannot pay a 15 per cent tax, and I am asking the Treasurer to reconsider the attitude of the Government to this issue and at least drop the tax to 10 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is half an hour left for debate on the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill, which introduces some sweeping changes across the whole gamut of the transport industry in Australia. It is an omnibus Bill-it covers areas of aviation, areas of road transport, areas of railways and shipping-and we are given but half an hour by this Government to discuss these changes.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst some of the features of this particular omnibus Bill are relatively minor-there are minor amendments to the Tasmanian railway system superannuation plan being upgraded-some quite significant aspects of the Bill should be debated to a much greater extent than the half an hour that has been allowed to us tonight by the Government.

I concentrate my comments on my areas of responsibility in the shadow ministry, namely, the amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988 and the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. As I said a little earlier, while some of these amendments are really quite minor, there are some aspects of this particular Bill that require some very close examination indeed.

Perhaps I could look firstly at the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. The amendments which are brought in by this particular Bill cover two main areas. The first is the provision of security at airports and the second is the requirement to change the accounting functions for the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC).

Honourable members will be aware that from 1 July this year the Federal Airports Corporation will be subject to income tax and these amendments change the situation so that the reporting year for the Federal Airports Corporation will now finish on 30 June rather than 31 March, as is presently the case.

The area covering airport security is welcomed by the Opposition. Airport security is to become a function of the FAC, which will be responsible for the provision of aviation security at all FAC airports. I understand, by virtue of these amendments, privately operated airports such as Cairns and Hamilton Island will be similarly responsible for their own security.

These provisions will relate only to the air side of airports, and will cover all security functions, including the anti-terrorist procedures. Obviously, this will bring us in line with what happens in most airports overseas. I understand the saving to the Government by making this move is something like $15.9m. The Opposition welcomes that particular amendment.

There are some matters I raise tonight on the Civil Aviation Act 1988. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) said that the amendments to the Act, governing the operations of the inspectors and investigators of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), will provide investigators with adequate and clearly defined powers. The Minister said:

These will be subject to strict safeguards to protect the rights of individuals against whom the powers may be exercised. The safeguard provisions proposed by this Bill are in line with similar provisions found in other Commonwealth legislation.

I have raised in the House before the very real concern, especially in the general aviation industry, of the activities of some of the inspectors within the Civil Aviation Authority. There is some concern within that particular part of the industry that the amendments tonight are really not going to help the situation as much as all of that.

I bring to the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon), who is at the table, clause 32aa, the appointment of investigators. One of the areas of concern is the fact that the CAA may appoint an officer to be an investigator. The Bill really does not give any indication of what is required to be an investigator for the CAA. Whether it be a pay clerk or whether it might be someone who might be highly qualified, there is no guarantee that this will be taken into account in these particular amendments contained in this Bill. I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to advise us whether or not in fact there will be that provision for the licensing of inspectors.

I also bring to the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary clause 32ac, the monitoring powers of those investigators exercised with consent. The industry has always had difficulty with CAA investigators who enter unattended hangars without permission to search the premises and the aircraft that might be in those hangars. It would appear that this clause implies that they can do so only with the consent of the occupier. Whilst they clearly cannot enter if consent is refused, it is not clear that they can do it if the consent is not available. I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to advise us, if he possibly can, whether or not the CAA investigators can in fact enter without consent when the facility is unoccupied. If that is the case, the legislation should clearly say so; otherwise it should state that access without permission is not allowed unless acting with a warrant.
There is also concern with clause 32ae, the offence powers exercised with consent. The section clearly states:
. . . the investigator may, with the consent of . . . the occupier of the premises:
(a) enter the premises; and
(b) search the premises for the thing; and
(c) if the thing is found-seize it.
There is some concern that this may conflict with clause 32ah of the Bill which authorises evidence to be seized without the occupier's consent.

The other area in question is clause 32aj, the power to require persons to answer questions and produce documents. This particular clause permits an investigator with a warrant to require anyone at all on the premises to answer any questions at all that may be put by the investigator or be subject to a fine of $3,000. I understand some legal opinion is being sought on this particular question, but it appears that these particular investigators would have more power than civil policemen. Even a common criminal is entitled to the right to refuse to answer any or all questions until protected by a court of law; yet, according to these particular amendments, someone could well be up for a $3,000 fine.

Clause 32ak, relating to powers in relation to aircraft, is also of some concern. This clause causes very great difficulty because it imposes no real restrictions on the investigator's power to stop and detain aircraft. While the power to stop and detain may be necessary, the reasons for exercising it should be clearly defined. It appears to me that the operators must be in clear violation of published CAA regulations or orders and any continued operation would be such as to endanger public safety.

There is concern that if these definitions are not clearly spelled out perhaps we should look towards amending these provisions in another place. I am sure the honourable member will help to clear up some of those points. There has been some very real concern within the industry about the operations of inspectors in the past. If that is cleared up, I am sure the industry will feel much happier with these particular amendments.

I turn now to section 98 of the principal Act, which is also being amended to clarify the CAA's power to make regulations in respect of the preparation and approval of all the technical documents specified in the Act. This includes flight manuals, operation manuals, procedure manuals, aircraft maintenance manuals and the like. We would welcome that particular part of these amendments.

The Government should be congratulated on-and indeed the industry is pleased with-the fact that at last the CAA and the Government generally are moving towards allowing aircraft operators to abide by the maintenance provisions set out by aircraft manufacturers. For the life of me, I have never really been able to work out why Australia should differ from other parts of the world in this regard.

In the case of the major overseas aircraft manufacturers, they should have a pretty fair idea of what is required on their aircraft. We need the provision brought about by these particular amendments to allow aircraft operators to abide by the technical provisions of those particular manuals. In fact, the requirements set out by the manufacturers will have to be maintained by the operators of aircraft in Australia.

It is not my intention to speak for too long on this particular Bill tonight, except to say that I think it is a great pity that we have no more than just half an hour to debate some aspects of these amendments. SPEECH.PARA: The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill which we are addressing this evening is an omnibus Bill dealing with a range of areas relating to transport. The area of interest to me is that dealing with the shipping side of life. The portion of the Bill referred to by the honourable member for Shortland, the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983, would be supported by all honourable members from both sides of the House. It is a Bill which we see in today's environment as essential to protect the maritime life around the Australian coastline.

Only last week in the House we debated the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill which was designed to try to ensure that all commercial shipping in excess of, I think, 70 metres in length, had a pilot on board to guide them through the very difficult waters of the Great Barrier Reef. That was designed specifically to avoid potential catastrophes such as we have seen fairly recently, unfortunately, on the television-catastrophes such as that involving the Exxon Valdez where many millions of barrels of oil were spilled into the ocean and caused untold damage to the environment in Prince William Sound and surrounding areas.

The Great Barrier Reef Amendment Bill was designed to try to prevent that type of catastrophe from occurring. The Opposition supported it wholeheartedly. Had it not been for the guillotine and the axing of our opportunity to speak on it, I would have had the opportunity to address an amendment which I had recorded in Hansard. It was designed to try to better protect our marine life and to ensure that pollution does not occur, and it would do that by opening up the pilotage service that operates on the Great Barrier Reef to ensure that there is some competition.

Honourable members would be interested to know that on the Great Barrier Reef at present there is a monopoly provider of pilot services. In order to ensure that the shipping industry complies with this legislation, it is important to keep the cost of pilot services down. For that reason, we had hoped to be able to draw to the attention of the House the fact that a little competition, either by way of an alternative pilot service operator or by enabling shipping companies to employ their own pilots full time or to have regular crew members properly qualified as pilots for those waters, would have added to the strength of the Bill by ensuring that the cheapest possible pilotage services were being provided on the Great Barrier Reef, thereby ensuring that shippers did not try to cheat the system by operating in those waters without a pilot. If we can provide an alternative to the monopoly pilot service in the Great Barrier Reef, we will have cheaper services and greater compliance with the legislation that we passed.

The Opposition supports this legislation. I personally support the amendments that relate to the prevention of pollution from ships. The specific provisions do a couple of things. Firstly, they increase the penalties for proven pollution at sea, and secondly, they ensure that notices can be issued not just to the master of the ship or to the shipowner but also to the ship's agent. This is an important amendment to the legislation, because it has been proved that, particularly with foreign-flag vessels, if there has been an instance of pollution at sea it is very difficult for the Australian Government to serve a notice on a foreign master or a foreign shipowner. One of the most practical ways of dealing with the problem is to serve the notice on the ship's agent here in Australia and, through the agent, ultimately to the shipowner or to the master of the ship. This is a sensible amendment, one which we support and one which will ensure that people who are guilty of polluting our seaways are served with a proper notice and are properly penalised.

The other aspects of the Bill deal with the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA). Some minor amendments relate to leave for the Chairman and members of the Authority and termination of those people's service to the Authority. Once again, the Opposition has no complaint with the proposals being put forward. Interestingly enough, a short time ago the Australian Maritime Safety Authority was the subject of a great deal of controversy over the disappearance of the yacht Rockin Robin. The crew members, whilst being watched and surveyed on board a life raft, were ultimately lost and never found again. That highlighted some deficiencies within AMSA.

After a great deal of pressure from the Opposition the Government held an inquiry. We thought that the inquiry would be a bit of a whitewash because it was going to be an in-house inquiry. In-house inquiries tend not to really delve into the problems and highlight them. However, the inquiry did, contrary to my own opinion, highlight a number of deficiencies that had to be corrected. I hope that in the passage of time since then those things have been corrected.

I note that a new Managing Director of AMSA has been appointed today. We look forward to his contribution to the improvement of search and rescue operations through AMSA. As he and the people who work for AMSA-a very dedicated group of people-are aware, lives depend upon their successful operations. In the case of the Rockin Robin we can see just how easily lives can be lost if a mishap occurs within the planning and operation of a search because of some mistake somewhere down the search and rescue line. We want to avoid that.

The Opposition complained bitterly about the shift of the Authority from Canberra to Newcastle. At the time we highlighted that no cost-benefit studies were being provided by the Government to justify the piling up of many millions of dollars in relation to the cost of shifting the Authority to Newcastle. We were proven to be right; the costs became quite untenable. To the great embarrassment of the Newcastle members of Parliament and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who promised that AMSA would be created in Newcastle, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) decided to renege on the promise and keep AMSA in Canberra. He did the right thing, even though it caused embarrassment to his Newcastle Labor Party colleagues.

Quite honestly, there were no legitimate arguments for taking AMSA from Canberra to Newcastle. The argument was very simplistically put that we had to have these things close to the sea. The simple fact is that we do not operate the search and rescue operation through AMSA with a pair of binoculars; it is all done electronically through communications methods and other things. That can be done equally as well in Canberra as in any country town in Australia, as long as there are adequate communication facilities. Taking it to Newcastle was a nonsense and was simply an exercise in pork-barrelling.

We are pleased to see that these matters before the House will strengthen the protection of our marine life by ensuring that proper penalties are being imposed on those people who are found guilty of polluting our seaways. We look forward to seeing more competition in Great Barrier Reef pilotage services to ensure that pilotage services there are being provided not by a monopoly operator but by a number of providers or that shipowners can employ their own full time pilots either as specialist pilots or as regular members of the crew, properly qualified, operating up and down those waters. By doing that, we ensure that people can afford the cost of protecting our maritime environment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Jobst garments, the special dressing suits used to flatten scar tissue of burn victims, beneficial in relieving the discomfort and itching experienced while scar tissue is fresh.
(2) Does the compression by a Jobst garment help minimise functional disability caused by scar contracture.
(3) Is there a rebate under Medicare for the cost of Jobst garments; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

It is a matter for each State to determine its priorities and the funds that are allocated between the many competing areas of State Government spending, including hospital and health services.

Traditionally, all States other than New South Wales have provided garments such as JOBST garments free of charge via the public hospital systems. The New South Wales Government recently announced that it would do likewise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 14 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he provide a detailed explanation of the Government's rejection of the Grains Council's submission which advocated a base price for wheat for the 1991 season.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government is acutely aware of the difficulties faced by wheat growers and by rural Australia generally. The severe downturn in wheat prices over the past twelve months has been caused by record world wheat crops in practically all major producing and trading countries and by the excessive subsidising practices of the European Community and the United States.

It is against this background that the Government gave very careful consideration to the Guaranteed Minimum Price (GMP) or so-called base price proposal of the Grains Council of Australia (GCA). It was rejected for several reasons which were detailed in a media statement I released on 26 March 1991.

In summary, the proposal was rejected because of the production and market distortions a GMP would create, the precedence it would set and because it would not necessarily help those farmers most in need.

With the situation in the wool industry, and assuming a normal season, a GMP for wheat had the potential to induce substantial over-production. If this eventuated and the world market remained depressed, the Government would be in the position of having exacerbated the problem and there would be pressure to not only continue the scheme but also to provide increased national interest cover to sell the excess wheat.

A GMP scheme would also create additional distortions in the domestic market, with a likely massive switch from other grains to wheat causing problems for these other industries in maintaining their marketing strategies. Domestic users of wheat would be forced to pay a higher than market price. There would also be pressure from growers in other industries for a GMP scheme.

In the Government's view, Australia should not attempt to enter the trade war, currently being waged by the EC and the USA, for the simple reason that Australia would be disadvantaged. Maintaining our credibility in the Uruguay Round was also a consideration in the decision. The Round offers the best hope yet Australia has of ending the damaging subsidising practices of the EC and US.
This Government has consistently steered away from industry specific assistance and instead has targeted assistance as much as possible to the individual.

In the wheat industry it is clear that the problems are more of a short-term nature caused by a depression in wheat prices. While many growers are in serious financial difficulties there are also many who are managing. Evidence of this is given by the fact that when the Australian Wheat Board offered a $30 per tonne equity draw-down from the 1988-89 pool earlier this year, over $140 million was not called on by growers. ABARE figures also show that while many growers will earn a negative income this year, 25% of growers will earn over $60,000 in net farm income.

Given this situation, the Government believes that assistance through the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) is a better way of targeting assistance to those farmers who really need it. It deals even handedly to individual farming families and provides a very effective use of limited Commonwealth funds.

The Commonwealth has therefore undertaken to increase its overall funding of the RAS from $62.45 million to up to $160 million in 1991-92. The structural adjustment component of the RAS or Part A (which includes capital restructuring and farm improvement measures) will receive $61.3 million in 1991-92. The Commonwealth's contribution to activate Part B of RAS will be $27.2 million which will provide for carry-on assistance through interest subsidies on carry-on finance for a period of two years, including the introduction of a special new provision, Debt Reconstruction with Interest Subsidies (DRIS). The balance of assistance funding is to be allocated to Part C of RAS to provide income support and re-establishment grants to farmers without prospects.

Overall, the Commonwealth's contributions to RAS, together with the State contribution if States provide the full amount of matching funds required for Part B and DRIS, are expected to underwrite rural borrowings to a level in excess of $1.4 billion for over 10,000 farmers. I have also indicated that total Commonwealth funding for the RAS could potentially be further increased to $220 million.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Primary Industries and Energy: Live Sheep Exports

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 9 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did large scale live sheep exports to the Middle East begin.
(2) How many ships are involved in the live sheep trade.
(3) How many sheep can be exported in the biggest of the ships.
(4) How many days, on average, does the journey take to the Middle East.
(5) What are the principal destinations of the sheep.
(6) What details are available of the numbers of sheep which die en route.
(7) Are veterinary officers employed on the ships; if so, who employs them.
(8) Has his Department ever sent officers to observe and report on the conduct of the live sheep trade; if so, when.
(9) What happens to the sheep on arrival at their port of destination.

(10) Are sheep slaughtered in the port of destination and then sent on as carcase or chilled meat to other Middle East destinations; if so, (a) what proportion of live sheep exported are so treated and (b) why cannot the sheep be slaughtered and processed in Australia.
(11) What export earnings did Australia receive from export of live sheep to the Middle East in (a) 1986, (b) 1987, (c) 1988, (d) 1989 and (e) 1990.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Live sheep were first traded to the Middle East region in 1959/60 with small shipments into the Persian Gulf. The trade escalated in the mid 1970's with the introduction of larger capacity ships and increased opportunities for trade with many of the Middle East countries. The expansion was generated by a demand for relatively low priced sheep to supply the expanding expatriate community within these countries, resulting in an overall trade in excess of 5 million head in 1979/80 and further expanding to a peak of 7.5 million in 1986/87.
(2) There are currently 16 ships involved in the Australian live sheep trade to the Middle East.
(3) Of these 16 ships 5 vessels can accommodate in excess of 100,000 head in any one consignment.

(4) The number of days entailed in each voyage are dependent on the location of the port of loading, ship speed and the location of the port of discharge. On average the voyage lengths are between 17 and 21 days.
(5) The principal destinations for the shipments of Australian live sheep at the present time are Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, UAE and Oman.
(6) Average annual mortality rates for consignments of Australian live sheep to the Middle East from 1981 to 1990 fluctuated from a high of 2.36% (1981) to a low of 1.64% (1987).

(7) Veterinary officers are employed on live sheep vessels in the following situations. Any vessel carrying sheep to Saudi Arabia was accompanied by a Commonwealth Government Veterinary Officer. This officer, was employed by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, to monitor the health and welfare of the consignment and prepare a supplementary health report for the Saudi quarantine authorities.

Commonwealth and State/Territory Government Veterinary Officers have also accompanied vessels on an ad hoc arrangement to undertake specific welfare and research investigations. These officers were employed by their respective Commonwealth/State/Territory Government departments. Occasionally, veterinarians may also be placed aboard the vessel by the exporter or the importer.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 9 April 1991:

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Transition from adult employment overseas to adult employment in Australia relies heavily on applying the skills and educational qualifications of the individuals concerned. The measures used to effect the transition from European to Australian employment apply equally to migrants from other regions.

Perhaps the most basic issue is that of English language training. My Department currently provides over $8 million specifically for the Advanced English Program for Migrants, as well as further adult literacy and English language training opportunities which are a feature of other Government labour market programs.

Building upon English language proficiency, the next most fundamental problem is the recognition, accreditation and application of overseas acquired skills in Australia. - establishing the cooperative development of national competency-based skill standards;
- improving access of skilled migrants to adequate education and training opportunities;
- improving information, advice and client services arrangements; and
- promoting relevant international developments to enhance skills recognition.

To coordinate implementation of this reform agenda, the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition (NOOSR) was established in my Department in July 1989. Further, in November 1989, the Government also established the National Advisory Committee on Skills Recognition (NACSR), chaired by Sir William Keys, to provide policy advice on skills recognition issues in Australia.

NOOSR and NACSR have a number of major achievements in employment and training of overseas trained migrants to their credit. Their activities currently range from promoting bridging courses and undertaking research into the development of national competency based standards for professions to improving assessment and accreditation arrangements and targeting employer attitudes to enhance employment prospects for migrants.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 15 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims made by a number of individuals and organisations that a trust fund was established by the Chifley Government to provide benefits to persons when they retired.

(2) Did the Chifley Government establish the National Welfare Fund; if so, (a) did it entail the investment of substantial funds for later distribution to contributors, (b) was a special social service tax levied to provide income for the fund, (c) were any funds or liabilities established to be met from the fund in the years that deposits were made, (d) did income exceed expenditure in years when the social service tax was collected and appropriated to the fund, (e) was the level of the social services tax tied to expenditure in the year of collection, (f) have the liabilities of the fund been met from Consolidated Revenue since the discontinuance of the social service tax, (g) what funds were in the trust account at (i) 1 July 1982 and (ii) the date the fund was wound up, (h) were or are there any legal provisions that credited tax payers with a redeemable asset as is claimed in material being circulated and (j) did the present Government derive a financial benefit when it discontinued the fund.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A trust account entitled ``The National Welfare Trust Fund'' was established in 1943. Section 6 of the National Welfare Fund Act 1943 (repealed on 22 May 1985) stated that:

Moneys standing to the credit of the National Welfare Fund shall be applied in making such payments as are directed by any law of the Commonwealth to be made from the Fund, in relation to health services, unemployment or sickness benefits, invalid and age pensions, widows pensions, family allowances, or other welfare or social services.
(2) The Curtin government established the National Welfare Fund in 1943, by Section 4 (1) of the National Welfare Fund Act 1943.
(a) Money standing to the credit of the Fund was invested. However, there is no evidence that funds were later distributed to contributors.

(b) Yes, a special social service tax was levied to provide income for the fund from 1943 to 1 July 1950. The Government of the day attempted to align proceeds from specific taxes introduced for financing social service expenditure (Social Services contributions) to the amount required for financing expenditure from the Fund. See also 2 (e).
(c) Unknown
(d) Yes, the Fund's receipts exceeded its expenditures by $370 million in the period from 1943-44 to 1951-52.

(e) There was no relationship between the social service tax and expenditure from the Fund. As a result, Income Tax and Social Service contributions were merged into a single levy from 1 July 1950. The Act was then amended to ensure that the income of the Fund would be approximately the same as if the Social Services Contribution had remained in force. In 1952 the Act was further amended, so that the amount paid to the Fund each year (from Consolidated Revenue) was equivalent to the amount expended from it.
(f) Yes, Clause 5 of the National Welfare Fund Act 1943 states:

There is payable out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, which is appropriated accordingly, for the purposes of the National Welfare Fund in each financial year, an amount equal to the amount of moneys paid out of the National Welfare Fund in that financial year.
(g) (i) There were no funds in the trust account at 1 July 1982.
(ii) There were no funds in the trust account on 22 May 1985, the day the trust account was closed.
(h) There are no legal provisions that credited tax payers with a redeemable asset, as is claimed in material being circulated.
(j) No

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 16 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the status of the Civil Aviation Authority's proposal to concentrate air traffic control on just two centres, Brisbane and Melbourne.
(2) Does the Government endorse the proposal.
(3) What are the air safety implications of the proposal.

(4) If Brisbane and Melbourne were the sole air traffic control centres and the Melbourne centre was forced to shut down as a result of computer malfunction or some other reason, would Perth be left without air traffic control.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has taken the decision to implement the Two Centre concept whereby all air traffic services (except those provided by control towers) may be supplied from two centres, planned for location in Melbourne and Brisbane.

The CAA is currently evaluating submissions from staff and staff associations which argue for the retention of facilities to provide approach and departure services (called Terminal Control Units) at major airports. The CAA has also received proposals from other sources concerning, inter alia, the siting of the two centres.

The CAA has recently announced that six companies will be invited to submit registrations of interest to be selected as prime contractor for the project. The companies are Hughes, IBM, NEC, Alenia, Siemens Plessey and Thomson-CSF. No Australian companies were included as none are in the business of providing large scale air traffic systems. The CAA is also still bound by Government policies on offsets.
Further consultation with the industry and unions will occur as the project's planning details are refined.
The CAA is a Government Business Enterprise charged with operating in a commercial manner. It is appropriate for the Authority to take decisions such as this on its intended strategic direction.

(2) The Government has no in principle difficulty with the proposal for an integrated air traffic control system and its key objectives of improved safety and lower costs to the aviation industry which plays such a vital role in the Australian economy.

(3) The proposals do not entail any decrease in the level of aviation safety; to the contrary, they will enable Australia to experience the benefits of the best air traffic systems technology available.

(4) Each of the two centres will be able to provide a limited back up to the other in the event of catastrophic failure. This otherwise ``spare'' capacity will be used for training in the normal course of events. If the Melbourne centre was to be disabled, Brisbane would be able to provide a service to Perth, albeit that service may be somewhat reduced from normal levels. This prospect would provide a better back up capability than presently exists in the event of destruction of the current Perth Air Traffic Services complex.
It should also be noted that Perth airport will continue to have its own Air Traffic Control Tower this will not be affected by the proposed changes.
